title: Contribute a first version of the documentation files
body:
The following resources will be necessary to get started with the project:

* README
* License
* Github templates

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the first version of the doc has been contributed.

title: Configure the build
body:
The build should at least trigger the following tasks

* run the linters (format and static analysis)
* run the tests with code coverage
* minify the code

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the commit has been merged.

title: Add a first version of the code
body: This first contribution should only contain the entry points of the HTML, CSS and JavaScript code.

title: NA
body: The pull request has been merged.

title: Add a first version of the dashboard
body: This dashboard will mainly be used to statically test of we will display our main elements. We will only display a static list of projects using cards for now.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the commit has been merged

title: Display the list of the projects
body: The dashboard will not end up showing all the projects. As such, we will need another page to display the list of the projects available.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the commit has been merged.

title: Display one project
body: Contribute a static page showing the details of one project.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the commit has been merged.

title: Connect the front-end to the back-end
body: The list of projects and the details of each project should be computed from the API of the server. As such some of our components will have to be transformed to stateful components.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the commit has been merged.

title: Define properly the kinds of state of the stateful components
body: Our stateful components are a bit too complex since we can't easily determine the various kinds of state that they will go through and how they will go from one state to another. In order to solve this issue, we will setup finite state machines showing precisely the list of their states and the available transitions to go from one state to another.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the commit has been merged.

title: Handle the error states of our stateful components
body: All of our stateful components are currently communicating with the server. As such, they have to deal with potential errors such as a server error or a response containing invalid data.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the pull request has been merged.

title: Handle the empty states
body: When our users will get started, the server will not contain any meaningful pieces of information. As such it is of the utmost importance to handle the blank state of our pages.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the pull request has been merged.

title: Remove the rendering from the stateful components
body: Our stateful components define how the user interface should be rendered. Separating both concerns in different components will allow us to reuse the rendering part of the code.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue since the commit has been merged.

title: Update the project's metadata for publication
body:
<!-- Help us manage issues by specifying the following information. -->

## Details
<!-- Check one of the following options with "x" -->
* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem all the time?
* [ ] Are you running the latest version?
* [ ] Did you check the documentation?
* [ ] Are you reporting this issue to the correct repository?
* [ ] Did you perform a search to check if the issue does not exist already?

## Current behavior
<!-- Describe how the issue manifests -->
The current project's metadata do not have enough information to be properly published on NPM.


## Expected behavior
<!-- Describe what the desired behavior would be -->
The projects metadata should have more information such as:

* description
* license
* issues
* repository

We will have to make sure that we use a proper name for the future. I think using @sirius/core would be a good solution. Since we can't delete anything on NPM, we will thus prepare things for this summer when we will start separating the project in various modules (@sirius/core and @sirius/app for example?). As a result, some APIs of the 0.1.0 release will be broken in the 0.2.0 release due to some refactoring.

## Steps to reproduce
<!-- For bug reports please provide the *STEPS TO REPRODUCE* and if possible a *MINIMAL DEMO* of the problem. -->


## What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?
<!-- Describe the motivation or the concrete use case -->
It will let us publish our project easily on NPM

title: Separate the app and core parts
body:
## Details * [x] Can you reproduce the problem all the time? * [x] Are you running the latest version? * [x] Did you check the documentation? * [x] Are you reporting this issue to the correct repository? * [x] Did you perform a search to check if the issue does not exist already? ## Current behavior Some of our generic components are a bit too dependent on the structure of the application. As an example, the ProjectSummaryCard display a link to a project but said link will always go to the URL ```/projects/:projectName```. We cannot reuse this component in an application where the project URL would be different. ## Expected behavior Our generic components should not depend on the URLs of our application. The current project should be separated in two different packages in this repository with a core package of generic components and an app package with the final application. The core package may not depend on react-router or it should at least let users define all the links in the generic components. Since lots of links have the same destination, a LinkProvider component could be introduced in order to compute the links in the application. This component would provide the proper links to any component thanks to the React context API. This would let anyone rewrite the links of our components easily. This API could look like this: ```javascript const linksDefinition = // To be defined ``` ```javascript const SomeComponent = (props) => { const { name, linkProvider } = props; const projectLinkURL = linkProvider.getLink('PROJECT', name); return (
{`Go to ${name}`}
); }; ``` This should probably occur after the 0.1.0 release. ## Steps to reproduce ## What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior? Our generic components should be reusable in any kind of applications. ## Environment Sirius Components version: X.Y.Z Browser in which the issue has been reproduced: * [x] Chrome (desktop) version XX * [x] Chrome (Android) version XX * [x] Chrome (iOS) version XX * [x] Firefox version XX * [x] Safari (desktop) version XX * [x] Safari (iOS) version XX * [x] IE version XX * [x] Edge version XX For Tooling issues: * Yarn version: XX * Node version: XX * Platform: Others:

title: Prevent transitions to undefined states

title: Use a component-based approach for text management
body:
<!-- Help us manage issues by specifying the following information. -->

## 🚀 Feature Request
<!-- Check one of the following options with "x" -->
* [x] Are you running the latest version?
* [x] Did you check the documentation?
* [x] Are you reporting this issue to the correct repository?
* [x] Did you perform a search to check if this feature has not been requested before?

## Expected behavior
<!-- Describe what the desired behavior would be -->
Text is the only concern which is handle by global CSS classes used pretty much anywhere in the code. Our CSS classes are not an API and they will be modified heavily in the future yet for this very problem we are treating them as such. As a result any refactoring of our text appearance or layout is complicated as seen recently.

We should removed global CSS classes for text and switch to a dedicated component for all text. The API of our text management would thus move from CSS classes to the component of the Text component. A Text component already exists in the Card but it should be removed in favor of a more generic one. 

## Environment

Sirius Components version: 0.1.0
<!-- Check whether this feature is not available in a newer version -->


Others:
<!-- Anything else relevant?  Operating system version, IDE, package manager, HTTP server, ... -->

title: Use a component-based approach for spacing
body:
<!-- Help us manage issues by specifying the following information. -->

## 🚀 Feature Request
<!-- Check one of the following options with "x" -->
* [x] Are you running the latest version?
* [x] Did you check the documentation?
* [x] Are you reporting this issue to the correct repository?
* [x] Did you perform a search to check if this feature has not been requested before?

## Expected behavior
<!-- Describe what the desired behavior would be -->
Using an [atomic design](http://bradfrost.com/blog/post/atomic-web-design/) approach which is implicitly what we are doing with React, there is an issue with the management of spacing. Since our atoms may be reused in very different situations, configuring their spacing cannot be properly done at the atomic level. It needs to be done by the component reusing them, not by them directly.

As such several components such as the Text component in Card need to be updated to remove their spacing policy in favor of a component based one which could be applied to anything. A card with a title and some text would then be changed to become something like this:

```javascript
import { Spacing } from '../spacing/Spacing';
import { MEDIUM, LARGE } from '../spacing/SpacingConstants';

const TestCard = () => {
  return (
    <Card>
      <PrimaryTitle label="My Title" />
      <Spacing top={LARGE} left={MEDIUM} bottom={MEDIUM} right={MEDIUM}>
        <Text>Some text...</Text>
      </Spacing>
    </Card>
  );
};
```

The text component here could be reused much more easily since it would not define its spacing policy. We could end up removing the ```layoutDimension``` constants from our CSS.

## Environment

Sirius Components version: 0.1.0
<!-- Check whether this feature is not available in a newer version -->


Others:
<!-- Anything else relevant?  Operating system version, IDE, package manager, HTTP server, ... -->

body: The variable ```--layoutDimension-xxxl``` should be removed or at the very least be renamed and moved from the global variables.

title: ECONNREFUSED error when launching browser with running fresh install on windows
body:
## 🐛 Bug Report
* [X] Can you reproduce the problem all the time?
* [X] Are you running the latest version?
* [X] Did you check the documentation?
* [X] Are you reporting this issue to the correct repository?
* [X] Did you perform a search to check if the issue does not exist already?

## Current behavior
After performing yarn start, the browser tab starts and displays:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42092903-905ea3da-7b78-11e8-9436-0fdb89b7241f.png)

Watching in process explorer, some node processes start, but one seems to die after starting--leaving the others running.

Command line displays:
Proxy error: Could not proxy request /api/dashboard from localhost:3000 to http://localhost:8080/.
See https://nodejs.org/api/errors.html#errors_common_system_errors for more information (ECONNREFUSED).
[HPM] Error occurred while trying to proxy request /api/dashboard from localhost:3000 to http://localhost:8080/ (ECONNREFUSED) (https://nodejs.org/api/errors.html#errors_
common_system_errors)

## Expected behavior
Dashboard should display correctly

## Steps to reproduce
yarn start from command line

## Environment
Sirius Components [latest]
Eclipse Photon [latest]
Sirius 6.0

Browser in which the issue has been reproduced:
Chrome Version 67.0.3396.99 (Official Build) (64-bit)
 
For Tooling issues:
* Yarn version: 1.3.2
* Node version: v9.5.0
* Platform: Windows 10 Enterprise version 1607

Others:

title: NA
body:
Looking at my Sirius install, the Sirius Server will not install.  I get this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42098065-ce528f1c-7b87-11e8-91ee-82eb480f2896.png)

title: NA
body:
Attempting the other (Experimental) Sirius installs [that I assume are also needed], I get similar results.  Any reason what I need to change?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42098243-51716d96-7b88-11e8-8b2e-b8483c377506.png)

title: NA
body:
I was finally able to isolate the dependencies needed for the Sirius Server et al by installing:
org.eclipse.jetty.servlets [9.0.0,10.0.0) dependencies.  That allowed the Server and Workflow experimental packages to install.  However, I get the same error in the browser (ECONNREFUSED).

Looking at the process explorer, there are 3 nodejs processes created and now they all continue to run.  The last created nodejs process gets a good amount of CPU run time as the browser tab spins up before the error in the workflow diagram element shows the error.

title: NA
body:
The HTTP traffic looks like:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42240646-f888c9d0-7ed5-11e8-9934-eaea5405999a.png)

title: NA
body:
Hi,

Sorry for the delay but I was away for a couple of days and since this code is quite new and I'm the one who wrote most of it, the team was waiting for me to return to answer this issue.

From what I understand from your very detailed messages, we may want to bundle the necessary Jetty bundle in our server feature, to simplify the installation. In any case, for the next release we will have [a dedicated product](https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/124325/) to launch the server so it will be easier to get started.

Now, your issue seems to be that the front-end cannot find the backend. There are two possibilities, either the server is not running or it does not run on the expected port (or something is very broken). In your Eclipse instance, you can open the Console view and start a new Host OSGi Console.

![](https://i.imgur.com/9y0soEq.png)

Once your OSGi console is running, you will be able to see the state of your Eclipse instance. In this case, you should first see if the server is running with ```ss org.eclipse.sirius.server```. You should see something like this:

![](https://i.imgur.com/tLBaJct.png)

If the components org.eclipse.sirius.server and org.eclipse.sirius.server.backend are not active, you may be missing the org.eclipse.sirius.server.ui.autostart component which, as its name implies, starts the server automatically. In any case, you can start the server manually by using ```start <ID>``` with ID being the identifier of the component displayed in the console. In my case, it would be ```start 524``` (see the previous screenshot for the ID of the server component in my Eclipse instance).

If the server is up and running like in my screenshot, then the issue must be coming from the fact that it did not start on the port 8080. While running the Sirius Component code in a development environment, it expect the server to be available on localhost:8080 (just like in the first error message that you have reported). By default, the Sirius server will tell Jetty to use a random port.

In order to tell Sirius to start the server on a specific port, an environment variable can be configured. You can thus launch your Eclipse instance with the following parameter to ensure that the Sirius server will be started on the port 8080 ```-DSIRIUS_SERVER_PORT=8080```.

In order to make sure that all of our environment variable look the same, this environment variable will be modified in the next release to ```-Dorg.eclipse.sirius.server.http.port=8080```.

title: NA
body:
Hi,

I must apologize for my delay getting back to you, but I was on a brief holiday.

Here is what I am trying with your assistance:

I start eclipse with the environment variable:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42453849-f3291992-835b-11e8-9970-6eab99a21c3a.png)

I run the example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42453881-0dc6f0da-835c-11e8-96a2-b78f5e8b3028.png)

And check the OSGi console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42453914-2422c5de-835c-11e8-9f1e-926abac13a04.png)

But I get the same error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7872418/42453945-3e174014-835c-11e8-97d9-96fa0f4f786d.png)

I am very new to Eclipse and Sirius.

title: NA
body:
Hi,

Could you add the environment variable in your eclipse.ini and could you make sure to have ```-console``` and ```-consoleLog``` too. You should have something like that in the end in your eclipse.ini

```
-startup
plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_xxxxxxxx.jar
--launcher.library
plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.xxxxxxxxxxxx
-console
-consoleLog
-vmargs
-Dorg.eclipse.sirius.server.http.port=8080
-DSIRIUS_SERVER_PORT=8080
```

Then start your Eclipse using a terminal and check what appears in the terminal. You should see something like this:

```
2018-07-10 08:42:22.000:INFO:oejsh.ContextHandler:Start Level: Equinox Container: f6054c6d-3728-4364-982b-77f2562a7625: Started o.e.j.s.ServletContextHandler@732d4054{/,null,AVAILABLE}
2018-07-10 08:42:22.046:INFO:oejs.AbstractConnector:Start Level: Equinox Container: f6054c6d-3728-4364-982b-77f2562a7625: Started ServerConnector@7fe943de{HTTP/1.1,[http/1.1]}{0.0.0.0:8080}
2018-07-10 08:42:22.046:INFO:oejs.Server:Start Level: Equinox Container: f6054c6d-3728-4364-982b-77f2562a7625: Started @3266ms
```

The part ```{HTTP/1.1,[http/1.1]}{0.0.0.0:8080}``` indicates on which port, here 8080, the Jetty server has been started.

title: Fix some compatibility issues with IE11
body:
<!-- Help us manage issues by specifying the following information. -->

## 🐛 Bug Report
<!-- Check one of the following options with "x" -->
* [x] Can you reproduce the problem all the time?
* [x] Are you running the latest version?
* [x] Did you check the documentation?
* [x] Are you reporting this issue to the correct repository?
* [x] Did you perform a search to check if the issue does not exist already?

## Current behavior
<!-- Describe how the issue manifests. -->
The front-end does not work with IE11.

## Expected behavior
<!-- Describe what the desired behavior would be -->
The project page should work properly with IE11. For that three issues need to be fixed.

* The use of [URLSearchParams](https://caniuse.com/#search=urlsearchparams) is not supported on IE11
* The use of [Array#includes](https://caniuse.com/#search=Array.prototype.includes) is not supported on IE11. It can be replaced by Array#indexOf and a check to ensure that it does not equals -1.
* The CSS does not work with IE11. Support for [Flexbox](https://caniuse.com/#search=flexbox) is buggy and support for [Grid](https://caniuse.com/#search=grid) is not compliant with the CSS specification. The proper solution may be to create a custom CSS with a HTML comment to restrict it to Internet Explorer.

```html
<!--[if IE]>
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="all-ie-only.css" />
<![endif]-->
```

Those solution will work but in order to maintain the projet over time, the proper solution would involve separating the workflow application from the other parts of the front-end in order to keep the IE11 hacks limited to a specific portion of the codebase.

## Steps to reproduce
<!--
For bug reports please provide the *STEPS TO REPRODUCE* and if possible a *MINIMAL DEMO* of the problem.-
If you have link to a codepen showing the issue or a standalone repo please link that!
-->
Open the front-end in IE11, nothing works.

## Environment

Sirius Components version: X.Y.Z
<!-- Check whether this is still an issue in the most recent version -->

title: NA
body: Thanks for the feedback. The need for a GitHub Access Token and how to confogure it for both NPM and Maven is now mentioned in [a new section in the README](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web#github-access-token).

title: Failed to collect dependencies at fr.obeo.dsl.designer.sample.flow:fr.obeo.dsl.designer.sample.flow:jar:1.0.5-SNAPSHOT
body: When building the project sirius-web-sample-application, fr.obeo.dsl.designer.sample.flow:fr.obeo.dsl.designer.sample.flow:jar:1.0.5-SNAPSHOT artifact can not be found.

title: NA
body:
You maven is not configured to pull artefacts from github 

You need to generate a github token ( details here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58919401/installing-packages-from-github-npm-registry-auth-error-401 )

Modify settings.xml in cloned sirius-web and add the token.

title: NA
body:
Thanks for the feedback. The need for a GitHub Access Token and how to configure it for both NPM and Maven is now mentioned in [a new section in the README](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web#github-access-token).

Modifying the `settings.xml` from the repo as mentionned above would work *if you run the build with `-s path/to/settings.xml`*, but it is dangerous to put your personal token in plain text in a file part of a Git repo, as you are a mistake away to push it to a public repo or PR.

It is safer to only put your token in the default `$HOME/.m2/settings.xml` outside of any Git clone, and let Maven use this (no need to use `-s path/to/settings.xml` as `$HOME/.m2/settings.xml` is the default).

title: How do I convert an existing Sirius application to Web?
body: A wiki for this would help.

title: NA
body:
There is some documentation about this available at https://ocpmodeler.com/doc/2020.10.0/help_center.html#_developer_guide.
It's an initial version that will be completed in future versions.

title: npm run build (failed)
body:
Hello ,

I have tried to launch npm run build

i have this issue
![2020-10-22 15_18_57-MINGW64__c_Project_sirius_sirius-web_frontend](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2742075/96877581-225cba00-147a-11eb-95f7-70caafe90297.png)

Do you have an idea ?

  Best regards

               Erwan

title: NA
body:
You need to generate an github access token .... details here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58919401/installing-packages-from-github-npm-registry-auth-error-401 


and then create a .npmrc file in frontend dir of sirius-web with following content
```
registry=https://npm.pkg.github.com/eclipse-sirius
//npm.pkg.github.com/:_authToken=<Token>
```

You also have to remove mention of  **"@obeo/sirius-components": "0.1.27",** from package.json and couple of other files like  
 **frontend/src/index.js 
 frontend/src/main/Main.js** 


This worked for me.

title: NA
body:
The error message about a missing `react-scripts` seem to indicate that you did not run `npm install` before `npm run build` (so `react-scripts` is not installed in `node_modules`) or that it failed half-way, maybe because of the token issue mentioned by @rkvsraman.

I have completed the README with (hopefully) all the feedback we've had for now, hopefully they are complete now.

Closing this, but do not hesitate to reopen if you still have the issue with the current instructions.

title: Update GraphQL Java to v15 or v16
body:
We are currently using [GraphQL Java 14.0](https://github.com/graphql-java/graphql-java/releases/tag/v14.0), released in January.
We should move to [v15](https://github.com/graphql-java/graphql-java/releases/tag/v15.0) or [v16](https://github.com/graphql-java/graphql-java/releases/tag/v16.0) (depending on the impact of the changes.

title: NA
body:
* [Breaking changes introduced in v15](https://github.com/graphql-java/graphql-java/pulls?q=is%3Apr+milestone%3A15.0+label%3A%22breaking+change%22)
* [Breaking changes introduced in v16](https://github.com/graphql-java/graphql-java/pulls?q=is%3Apr+milestone%3A16.0+label%3A%22breaking+change%22)

title: NA
body:
Actually, GraphQL Java 16.0 seems to have an ugly bug, fixed in the just released 16.1: https://github.com/graphql-java/graphql-java/releases/tag/v16.1
We'll update to 16.1.0 instead of 16.0.

title: Update frontend compilation target to ES2019
body:
We are currently targeting ES2020 (see `jsconfig.js`), but this reduce the compatibility with not-so-old browsers. Moving to ES2019 should not have much of an impact (slightly larger bundles maybe, we'll need to measure).
Some adaptation may also be needed on the `sirius-web` side.

title: NA
body:
The overhead in bundle size seems negligible:

![Capture-2020-11-24_10-45-16](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/100099192-60754100-2e5f-11eb-9ae3-78a69086f50b.png)

title: Update to a more recent version of Guava
body: We use Guava in a few places, mostly for its cache, but use a very old version (v15). We should update to the latest (v30, released this month) to benefit from any fixes and/or performance improvements since then.

title: Replace our custom GraphQL hooks with Apollo Client
body:
Our frontend uses custom-build React Hooks, defined in `src/common/GraphQLHooks.ts`. They started simple, but became more complex over time and there are more features we would like to have and it does not make sense anymore to stay on a custom implementation.

This ticket's goal is to adopt [Apollo Client](https://github.com/apollographql/apollo-client) and replace all the custom code we have with the equivalent from Apollo. This concerns at least the hooks themselves, but maybe other parts too.

title: OnboardArea instanciated even when a representation is open
body:
## Steps to reproduce:

1. Open a diagram (create a project, model & diagram if needed). The "Onboarding Area" is not visible.
2. Open the browser Dev Tools on the "Network" tab. Clear it.
3. Refresh the browser's page.

Among the GraphQL requests triggered by the refresh and visible in the Netwotrk tab, there is one for the `getOnboardData` query which should not be triggered in this case. If you look in the "Initiator" tab for this request, the stack shows that the `OnboardArea` has been instanciated:

![Capture-2020-11-26_10-02-11](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/100331929-0bf1d300-2fd1-11eb-8ea6-9f8436753712.png)

title: NA
body: The initial scenario mentions relaoding the page to trigger the issue, but the problem is more general. If you bookmark the URL of a specific diagram and then open it in another fresh tab, the issue will appear also. We are explicitly opening a specific diagram, there is no reason for the onboard area to get instanciated.

title: Discriminate the jar path in the web resource URL
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specify the version** :
  latest
* [x] **I have specify my environment** : 
  All

### Screenshots

None

### Steps to reproduce

Two meta-models with the same EClass name will produce an icon path conflict :
```
"/Users/jdoe/.m2/repository/sample1/sample1-6.1.0.202006290907.jar!/icons/full/obj16/Relationship.png"
"/Users/jdoe/.m2/repository/sample1/sample2-6.1.0.202006290910.jar!/icons/full/obj16/Relationship.png"
```

### Expected behavior

I propose to introduce a prefix in the resource URL.

The goal of this fix is to discriminate a resource by it jar path.
To avoid to expose the real jar path (private to the project/server), we will hash it.

Example:
`"/Users/jdoe/.m2/repository/sample1/sample1-6.1.0.202006290907.jar!/icons/full/obj16/Relationship.png"`
Will produce a final url 
`http://localhost:8080/api/images/hash/588d4998-b86a-30a6-a9b9-9ffe2ff7d142/icons/full/obj16/Relationship.png"`

### Actual behavior

The actual implementation will produce a final url in conflict (the first jar win)
`"http://localhost:8080/api/images/icons/full/obj16/Relationship.png"`

title: NA
body: I'm not sure we want the `!` in the URL. It does not seem needed and could lead do encoding/deconding issues. It's part of [the reserved characters](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-2.2) in the URI syntax.

title: NA
body: It's an error. My bad. I will fix the description.

title: NA
body:
The hashing strategy needs to be secure in order to prevent someone from accessing anything on the file system, which would be a critical security issue. For that, we should not blindly trust the hash provided by the end user and still only authorize access to some paths allowed by the specifier. The hash should not be easily decrypted too.

Having said that, why not hash the whole path to have something like `http://localhost:8080/api/images/HASH.png`?

title: NA
body:
> The hashing strategy needs to be secure in order to prevent someone from accessing anything on the file system, which would be a critical security issue. 
> For that, we should not blindly trust the hash provided by the end user and still only authorize access to some paths allowed by the specifier. 

The hashing strategy : 
The hash is valid only if the hash has been generated by the server (stored in the map first...).
It means that the map is a kind of white list of trust paths.

> The hash should not be easily decrypted too.
You are right. We can use a random strategy or a secure hash algorithm to avoid an easily decrypted exploit.
The random strategy may be annoying for a "REST" usage of images URL.
At each server reload... all old image URLs get a 404.

> Having said that, why not hash the whole path to have something like `http://localhost:8080/api/images/HASH.png`?

It's a good idea to give a shorter URL.
The map will be bigger but it sounds reasonable to me.
The hash function will be used more frequently but it sounds also reasonable to me.

title: Support of unsynchronized mode
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior
Provide a way to unsynchronized a graphical element and it semanticCandidate expression.

An unsynchronized graphical element:
- must be create intentionally with a tool
- can be deleted with a delete tool -> the standard behavior will be to delete the unsynchronized graphical element (the semantic element behind will not be deleted)
- will disappear if it related semantic element does not exist anymore (Refresh behavior)

### Cuttings backs
- Handle only graphical nodes (Edge still 100% synchronized)
- Handle only programmatic contributions (This implementation does not handle yet an unsynchronized node that come from an odesign)

### Potential side effects
- Diagram refresh
- Create node tool
- Delete tool

### Describe alternatives you've considered
We have study an incremental refresh strategy to implement this behavior based on the [React approach](https://reactjs.org/docs/reconciliation.html).

The current state of this experimentation:
We don't need an incremental refresh to implement an unsynchronized mode.
We can give the previous unsynchronized element thanks to the variableManager without implement a "React reconciliation" pattern. 
The render method will clone the previous unsynchronized element and re-render it props (according that the semantic element behind isn't deleted).

This "React reconciliation" pattern could be study for a performance issue but it's not this subject here.

body:
### Problem

We need to provide a drag'n drop tool to drag an item from the explorer to the diagram in order to properly support unsynchronized diagrams.

### Solution

- Only one drop tool by diagram will be considered

title: Add a connector tool
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

Provide a magic edge tool. 
A magic edge tool will be available on a graphical element source if at least one edge tool can be created on it.
The target can apply algorithm is a delegation pattern. (At least on edge tool should be valid on this target)
After a target selection, the user will select the expected create edge tool.

### Cuttings backs

- Handle only programmatic contributions (This implementation does not handle yet a magic tool that come from an odesign)

### Potential side effects

contextual palette/invoke tool

### Describe alternatives you've considered

The user could select the expected create edge tool before to select a target.
In an ideal implementation, we could choose between these both strategies.

title: Add support for the multi-selection API
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

We should be able to select several tree/diagram elements.

We can use the CTRL+Click or 🍎 +Click to select several items.
Il a diagram, the CTRL+A should select all elements.

This multi-selection will give :  
- Multi delete
- Multi drag'n drop

### Cuttings backs

- SHIFT+Click or SHIFT+TOP or SHIFT+BOTTOM not handled in the explorer

### Potential side effects

- Delete tool
- Drop tool
- All selection dependent behaviors.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None

----

### :warning: **UPDATE**
The scope in 2022.01.0 was reduced compared to what is described above, and only contains the necessary API changes. Multi-selection in the explorer or on diagrams is not yet supported from the end-user point of view.

title: Add a diagram dirty state
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

There is a **_time laps_** between an invoke mutation and the related refresh.
This **_time laps_** involves some strange UX behaviors that we can avoid with a dirty state flag.

Use case:
* T0: A mutation (Label edit/invoke delete tool/invoke node or edge tool) is triggering. There is two ways:
* * T1: the mutation succeed
* * *  T2:  a diagram refresh happens
* * T1': the mutation failed

During these **_time laps_** (T0/T2 or T0/T1'), the diagram is in a dirty state.
We should avoid to propose the contextual palette when the user select a diagram element (especially after an invoke tool)

This proposition is based on a premise: **a mutation in success will always update something and throw a diagram refresh**
This proposition may be invalid if this premise is (or becomes) invalid.

### Cuttings backs

None

### Potential side effects

- Contextual palette

### Describe alternatives you've considered

We could involve the dirty state only between (T1/T2)

title: NA
body:
I'm not sure "dirty" is the best name for the intermediate state. I don't have a better name (maybe "busy"? or "waiting"? not fond of it but I can't find a better alternative at the moment). The usual meaning of "dirty" is more "contains changes which have not yet been saved on permanent storage", which is not the case here.

Side note: it's time *lapse* not *laps*. Laps exists but is somehting else.

title: NA
body:
I am not sure where this premise `a mutation in success will always update something and throw a diagram refresh's coming from` but it does not exist anywhere in the architecture.

A mutation triggers something to be performed on the project. If the mutation is successful, something may occur which may trigger a refresh.

title: Diagram elements should have a stable id across refreshes
body: Currently when we refresh a diagram we make sure the diagram's id itself is kept (as it is referenced by the rest of the system), but all the elements inside the diagram get completely new, random UUIDs every time. This prevents important features, like for example detecting which elements are new when the client receives an update so that it can highlight/focus them (among others).

title: Improve our dependency management
body:
We should improve the organisation of our package.json:

- Our `devDependencies` should only contain development tools
- Our `peerDependencies` should only contain the necessary projects (react, react-dom)
- Most of our regular dependencies should be in `dependencies`

We should also update our various dependencies since some of them are quite outdated.

This work will also be influenced by the new dependency resolution algorithm from npm 7. After the integration of this work, npm 7+ will become the recommended version to develop Sirius Components and Sirius Web applications. Working with previous versions of npm will still work but you will have to resolve the installation of `peerDependencies` by yourself as usual.

title: Use an UUID to identify a Node or an Edge
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior
According to the following PR feedback
https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/pull/140#discussion_r533488100

We should identify nodes and edges with an UUID (and use an UUID in the graphQL API).

The NodeMappingConverter, the idProvider give a string ```UUID.randomUUID().toString()``` -> we can remove the toString...
The EdgeMappingConverter, the idProvider give a string ```sourceId + " --> " + targetId + " - " + count``` -> we could transform this string in a UUID ```UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes```.

This implies :
* update graphQL API
  * Use @GraphQLID annotation for nodeIds/edgeIds in IDiagramInput implementations
* use UUID for
  * Node#id
  * NodeDescription#idProvider
  * NodeElementProps
  * Edge#id
  * EdgeDescription#idProvider
  * EdgeElementProps
  * IDiagramService#findNodeById
  * IDiagramService#findEdgeById

We should replace the idProvider type from Function<VariableManager, String> to Function<VariableManager, UUID>.

### Cuttings backs

We should probably do the same job with Label/ToolSection/ITool.
The Label id has a suffix pattern that we should review but it makes sens to cut this work in another issue. (To open before close this issue...) @see EdgeMappingConverter.convert and LabelDescription.LABEL_SUFFIX.

### Potential side effects

* Diagram refresh
* invoke tool / delete

title: NA
body:
> The NodeMappingConverter, the idProvider give a string `UUID.randomUUID().toString()` -> we can remove the toString...
> The EdgeMappingConverter, the idProvider give a string `sourceId + " --> " + targetId + " - " + count` -> we could transform this string in a UUID `UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes`.

For the edges, this is similar to the approach taken in https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/pull/139, which builds a discriminant by concatenating (in a string) all the ids / parameters which uniquely identify an element and then builds the final id using `UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes`.

Indeed, in my patch linked above I had not modified the `idProvider` for edges, because the existing logic guarantees it will be stable as long as the `sourceId` and `targetId` are (which the patch ensures). Well, except for the iteration order which determines the `count`. Maybe this part of the edge id discriminant should be replaced with the id of the edge description? The triplet `sourceId`, `targetId` and `descriptionId` should be both unique and stable, and this would unify the handling of all ids.

title: NA
body: This has been merged in master but @pcdavid's comment regarding future improvements on the generation of the edge id are still valid. We should keep that in mind.

title: Remove usage of the deprecated DirectProcessor
Improve the consistency and usages of useProject()
body:
The hook `useProject()` was created in order to retrieve in a similar fashion some information regarding the current project for top level components of a a specific set of views. From there, it has been overused without fully understanding the consequences of its use. It should probably have been deleted at this point.

After that it has been provided an additional capability with a dedicated subscription which makes it a provider of both synchronized data and unsynchronized data. While this new capability may give it a reason to stay around, it creates even more issues with the various places where it has been used without understanding its role.

title: Remove the use of the inefficient variableManager.getVariables().get(xxx) pattern
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

There are still quite a lot of places where the code uses the following code pattern to get the value of a single variable:
```java
Object xxx variableManager.getVariables().get("xxx");
```

The problem is that `getVariables()` will recursively build a `Map` with all the accessible variables, and then we use that map to do a single `get` on it and drop it. That's a lot of work and allocations for a single variable lookup.

The `getVariables` method can be useful to get a complete snapshot of all the available variables in some case, e.g.:
* if we know we will look at several variables in it;
* most commonly, because we need to pass the complete `Map<String, Object>` to `AQLInterpreter.evaluateExpression(Map<String, Object>, String)`

In all other cases, for a single variable lookup the `VariableManager.get(String, Class<T>)` should be prefered as it is strictly more efficient for single lookups: it stops iterating as soon as the requested variable is found and does no allocation.

### Cuttings backs

Some uses of the pattern, in particular in tests, are probabaly fine, but I think it would be better to use the more efficient API everywhere except in specific cases so that it becomes the "natural" choice.

Maybe we should rename `getVariables` to something else to make it clear that it actually does quite a lot of work and is probably not the first choice when you need to lookup a single value. `getAllVariablesSnapshot()` or something like that?

### Potential side effects

Improved performance. Maybe not measurable in all cases, but from earlier measures, the deep map copies performed by `getVariables` was visible in some parts of the refresh.
I don't see any cases for negative side effects or risks.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None.

title: Ignore sequence diagrams description when transpiling VSMs
body:

* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** : latest
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : all

### Steps to reproduce

Create a Sirius Web app using a VSM which defines one or more sequence diagrams (which are not supported).

### Expected behavior

The sequence diagrams definitions should be ignored, and not available to the end user as possible diagrams to create.

### Actual behavior

Sequence diagrams are made available, and converted using the rules for normal diagrams (which make no sense for them). When instanciated, the result is completely broken.

title: Add support for inverse references navigation
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

Sirius Desktop supports the `eInverse()` AQL service in its intepreted expressions to navigate "backwards" on EMF references in the semantic model. This feature is used in a lot of existing VSMs, but we do not support it as it requires setting up AQL properly for that.

### Cuttings backs

* Make the feature configurable (see below).
* Make the feature lazy (see below).

### Potential side effects

The addition of an `ECrossReferenceAdapter` increases the memory footprint. If that is an issue, maybe this should be configurable (or the adapter installed lazyly on the first invocation of `eInverse` in a given project).

### Describe alternatives you've considered

* Use one of the `EcoreUtil.UsageCrossReferencer.findAll()` on every call to `CrossReferenceProvider#getInverseReferences`. This would avoid the memory overhead, but replace it with a *very* costly operation on every invocation (rebuild a full `UsageCrossReferencer` each time).

title: Our dependency to Sirius RCP makes us dependent on outdated versions of EMF, Guava, etc
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have specified the version** :
- latest
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : 
- All

### Steps to reproduce

The parent pom.xml of Sirius RCP has a dependency to the maven plugin used to build Acceleo 3 modules. As a result, depending on Sirius RCP makes us depend on:

```
    <dependency>
    	<groupId>org.eclipse.acceleo</groupId>
    	<artifactId>org.eclipse.emf.ecore</artifactId>
    	<version>2.10.2.v20150123-0348</version>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
    	<groupId>org.eclipse.acceleo</groupId>
    	<artifactId>org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi</artifactId>
    	<version>2.10.2.v20150123-0348</version>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
    	<groupId>org.eclipse.acceleo</groupId>
    	<artifactId>org.eclipse.emf.common</artifactId>
    	<version>2.10.1.v20150123-0348</version>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
    	<groupId>com.google.guava</groupId>
    	<artifactId>guava</artifactId>
    	<version>10.0.1</version>
    </dependency
```

As a result, we have two versions of EMF Ecore, EMF Ecore XMI, EMF Common and Guava in our classpath. Any minor change which would change the order of the classpath resolution would make those versions used instead of the newer ones.

title: NA
body: If I am not mistaken, it seems that a third version of EMF is coming from somewhere else too. I have not yet determined from where but I'll look into it.

title: Feature request: plugin support?
body:
I'm planning to use [Acceleo](https://marketplace.eclipse.org/content/acceleo) to generate code of my model. 
Acceleo is a plugin for Sirius desktop, I'd like to be able to use it to generate code within Sirius-web (without having to open Sirius desktop).

Is this something that you could support in the future?

title: NA
body:
Hi,

This kind of thing is already possible using the existing mechanisms.

A concrete Sirius Web application is built on Spring Boot, which has its own extensibility mechanisms built-in.

To add something like Acceleo support you would need to:
* implement the actual generation service in a new module for the backend, see for example all the existing ones at https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/tree/master/backend. Acceleo is available as Maven artifacts on https://repo.eclipse.org.
* add an API entry point (either REST or GraqhQL) to your backend so that the frontend can call this new service. If you chose a REST endpoint, you can use the normal Spring Boot APIs to register a new controller. If you chose GraphQL, see `org.eclipse.sirius.web.graphql.utils.schema.ITypeCustomizer` and `org.eclipse.sirius.web.graphql.utils.schema.ITypeProvider` for how to extend the Sirius Web GraphQL Schema with your own types and additional fields.
* modify the frontend code to add the required UI elements to trigger the backend service. At the moment the only way to do this is to fork the `sirius-components/frontend` code.

title: Fix invalid use of async / await in WebSocketDiagramServer
body:
In SiriusWebWebSocketDiagramServer, there are multiple async functions that are not called from async functions. The whole usage of async / await in this class cannot possibly work since we are called by a framework, here Sprotty, that cannot know that it should use async to call our methods.

As a result, we can have very subtle lifecycle bugs with React where some parts of the code are executed asynchronously.

title: Create a "New Modeler" page
body:
This is part of the overall feature to support modeler definition directly inside Sirius Web.

* A new entry named "New modeler" will be added in the project's context menu.
* It will only be visible/enabled for user with _ADMIN_ rights on the project.
* When triggered, the menu will open a new page with a simple form, similar to the current "New project" page, to enter the name of the new modeler and submit.
* When submitted, the new page will send a mutation request to the backend to create the modeler, receive the corresponding editing context, and redirect to the project edition page setup on this new editing contex.

The whole infrastructure to actually create modelers and the corresponding editing context will come later in separate tickets.
The first iteration here will focus on creating the UI and a first version of the mutation needed, with a dummy implementation in the backend.

title: Create a new page to manage modelers
body:
This is part of the overall feature to support modeler definition directly inside Sirius Web.

* A new entry named "Modelers" will be added in the project's context menu.
* It will only be visible/enabled for user with ADMIN rights on the project.
* When triggered, the menu will open a new page with a list of the modelers associated to the project.
* Each modeler has a Name and a Status (_Draft_ or _Published_).
* Each modeler has a context menu with 3 entries:
  * _Rename_
  * _Publish_ (only enabled if the modeler is currently a _Draft_)
  * _Delete_

The whole infrastructure to actually create modelers and the corresponding editing context will come later in separate tickets.
The first iteration here will focus on creating the UI and a first version of the GraphQL Schema (types, queries, mutations needed), with a dummy implementation in the backend.

The menu entry:

![Capture d’écran de 2021-01-05 09-06-01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/103622088-7c780200-4f36-11eb-9e21-9070236ed496.png)

title: Define and implement a simple DSL for describing data schemas
body:
This is part of the overall feature to support modeler definition directly inside Sirius Web.

* We will need a way for modeler authors to describe their business domain as a "metamodel" (though we will not use that terminology).
* For the first MVP, we will define a simple version with just the minimum features.
* To simplify the implementation we will rely on Ecore, both at runtime and for the serialisation, but this should be seen as an implementation detail invisible to modeler authors, and is subject to change later on.

We'll start with an ADR to discuss the concepts and terminology we want to use, and how they map to an Ecore-based implementation.

- [ ] Define the concepts we want to expose in the DSL in an ADR
- [ ] Make it possible to create and edit model instances of this DSL in the explorer and properties view. The MVP will use Ecore as an implementation, and simply expose a limited subset of it, with different names, in the UI.
- [ ] Add a simple "Ecore Tools"-like diagram to edit these elements.

title: Make GeneralPurposeTestCases more flexible regarding the copyright years and assignees

https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/master/backend/sirius-web-tests/src/test/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/tests/GeneralPurposeTestCases.java#L80 hard-codes the string "Copyright (c) 2019, 2020 Obeo" as expected in the copyright headers.

It should be made more flexible to allow different years (2021) and copyright assignees (other than Obeo).

title: Introduce Editing Context to stop depending on the concept of project
body:
Currently, the modelers available to end-users of Sirius Web must be defined and deployed statically at build-time (programmatically using our APIs or using the Sirius Desktop compatibility layer and an exisiting VSM).
We want to support the complete definition of modelers directly in Sirius Web.
This includes both the definition of custom _data schemas_ (metamodels) and _representation descriptions_ (diagrams, forms, etc.).

Following the general approach of Sirius Desktop, both the custom data schemas and representation descriptions will be defined using the same tools as the actual end-user's domain models/diagrams.

In the current state, when inside a given project, the metamodels and diagram descriptions available are taken from a global, static state.
We need to introduce a new indirection for a project to point to a (set of) modelers (metamodels & representation description) that it wants to use *and which are defined as Sirius Web documents*.

Define a shared vocabulary
body:
Given our long history with Sirius Desktop and the way it used modeling and EMF-specific terms, we tend to reuse these (at least in our discussions).
For Sirius Web, we do not want to be limited to EMF, or even a modeling/MDE point of view, se we need to use different terms.

We need to decide on a common vocabulary, both for the user-visible elements (e.g. do we talk about "Documents", or "Models"? is it "Modeler" or "Studio", or do both exist but represent slightly different things?) and also more internally on the technical terms.

title: Improve the typing of our components
body: Improve our usage of TypeScript in order to have a better development experience starting with the diagram-related components.

title: NA
body: Closing this issue, additional improvements will be made with other issues.

title: Share a common fallback MaterialUI theme
body: Most of the application that will be created on top of Sirius Components will have to respect a specific set of constraints for their theme customization. While those constrains are not set in stone, we can share a fallback theme with some defaults that can be used to get started.

title: Make modelers persist in the database
body: Make sure the data structure used to represent modelers introduced in issues #219 and #220 is properly persisted in the database.

title: NA
body: Merged on master.

title: Fix support for EMF composed images
body:
`org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.services.ObjectService` assumes that `org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.services.ObjectService` can only return an `URL` or an `URI`. This is false for at least Ecore, which can return `ComposedImages` to overlay decorators. See `org.eclipse.emf.edit.provider.ItemProviderAdapter.overlayImage(Object, Object)` for example.

In that case ObjectService returns `null`, which causes NPEs when trying to use it.

title: How to upload a project?
body:
After creating a new project, downloading works fine and get 3 JSON file of the model but I wonder how to upload the project by using the same model file containing the 3 JSON? the upload doesn't work at all when I drag one single JSON and then click the upload button.
![截屏2021-01-19 下午7 59 52](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13996643/105080393-0a083580-5a91-11eb-817d-e59a70c570c6.png)

title: NA
body:
Sorry, I missed your question.

When you download a *project*, you should get a zip archive with all the current contents of the project (models and diagrams).
Uploading expects such an archive as input, and will create a new project with the same state as what was stored in the archive.

You can also download & upload individual models, but it's a different mechanism. "Upload project" expects a full project archive, not an individual file.

See the dopcumentation at https://ocpmodeler.com/doc/2020.10.0/help_center.html#_download_upload fro more details on these.

title: Add support for defining simple domain models
body: The initial implementation will be based on Ecore, but only expose a subset of it and use different names.

title: NA
body: Already in the scope of #221

title: Add support for non-EMF documents
body:
We currently only support EMF models as documents.
Most of the architecture actually has very little adherence to EMF, but there are still a few places which either assume it or are simply not flexible enough to allow for alternate implementations to be provided.

This ticket is about removing these limitations.

Note that that we do not simply want projects/editing contexts which use non-EMF documents/models, but support documents of different kinds inside the same project/editing context (though without interdependencies between them, at least as far as the framework is concerned).

The first usage, which will drive this work, is the definition of studios, and in particular diagram definitions.

title: NA
body:
General approach envisioned:

1. isolate the current dependency towards EMF in `DocumentService` and related and move the generic implementations into `sirius-web-services`;
2. add a notion of "type" to `Document` (probably a simple string). Type-specific implementations are delegated to some handler (`IEditingContext[PersistenceService]` maybe?)
3. add support for mixing multiple types of documents inside a single project or editing context.

The `IDocumentService` interface currently has only a single implementation, `org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.services.DocumentService`.
In practice, the only way this really depends  on EMF is in the `getBytes()` method, which is only used in two places:
- `org.eclipse.sirius.web.spring.controllers.DocumentController`: REST endpoint to download the content of a document.
- `org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.services.ProjectExportService`: produce a zip archive with the whole content of a projet.

_Side note_: `getBytes()` seems to do unneeded work when asked for a JSON version of the document. I'll open a separate ticket with a fix for that.

The `getBytes()` method should be removed from `IDocumentService`.
It could be moved to `IEditingContext`, at least in a first step.
Or maybe `IEditingContextPersistenceService`?
Or some other abstraction that emerges after a few steps.
I'll go with `IEditingContext` in the first patches to move forward, but this may change afterwards.

After this step, `DocumentService` (and `DocumentMapper`) can be moved to `sirius-web-services`.

_Next_: `CreateDocumentEventHandler`, `DeleteDocumentEventHandler`, `RenameDocumentEventHandler` and `UploadDocumentEventHandler` also have limited adherence to EMF, so it should be extracted in a similar way, and the now generic implementations moved to `sirius-web-services`. More details later.

title: NA
body: Actually `IEditingContext` does not have access to `Document` now that it has moved to `sirius-web-core-api`, so `getBytes()` will have to be somewhere else.

title: Unneeded work in DocumentService.getBytes() when using JSON resource kind
body:
When `org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.services.DocumentService.getBytes(Document, String)` is called with `RESOURCE_KIND_JSON`, it:
* gets the document's `content` which is already in JSON to create an EMF model
* serializes this model back to JSON

This is completely useless in this case, and we can simply return the document's `content` as is.

This method is used in `ProjectExportService` to produce the project archive with all models/documents as JSON files.

In my tests, on a simple projet with just "Big Guy" (17k semantic elements), the shortcut reduces the project export time from about 1500ms to about 360ms, with not difference in the resulting zip file.

title: The explorer definition depends on EMF
body:
Currently then only implementation of `IExplorerDescriptionProvider` we have is `org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.compatibility.explorer.ExplorerDescriptionProvider`, which depends on EMF.

It should be extracted and work on any kind of models/documents and objects inside of them.

This will require moving some APIs like `get(Root)Elements()`, `hasChildren()` and `getChildren()` into more generic APIs like `IEditingContext` and `IObjectService`.

title: NA
body: This implementation does not exist anymore in Sirius Components

title: AQL and Spring Boot use different versions of ANTLR
body:
When using the sample application, I get the following message on the console (the first time an AQL expression is evaluated I suppose):

```
ANTLR Tool version 4.7.2 used for code generation does not match the current runtime version 4.8
ANTLR Runtime version 4.7.2 used for parser compilation does not match the current runtime version 4.8
```

We are currently using AQL 7.0.0, which has been built using ANTLR 4.7.2, but the version we get in the classpath (since Spring Boot 2.4.1?) seems to be ANTLR 4.8.

body: We should switch to the same version as the latest release of hibernate

title: NA
body:
Thanks for the report.

From the look of the stack, it seems there are actually two separate issues:
* `Edge.toString()` assumes all its labels are non-null, but the `Edge.Builder` does not guarantee this. Probably voluntarily as the normal pattern used for the other fields is correctly followed (`Objects.requireNonNull()`).
* The reason `Edge.toString()` is invoked at all is to create an error message for an exception indicating a duplicate key (`Collectors.duplicateKeyException`). In `EdgeRequestor`, the call to `Collectors.toMap(Edge::getTargetObjectId, Function.identity())` assumes all edges have disting `targetObjectId`, which is wrong.

I'll open two separate issues in eclipse-sirius/sirius-components for these, and report here when they are fixed.

title: NA
body: Both underlying issues should be fixed in sirius-components 0.2.4 (just released).

title: Update the way our data structure are created
body:
I tried using our raw APIs to build a diagram definition programmatically, and the experience is rather frustrating.
Our APIs require the use of builders (which is fine) and the builders' `build()` methods enforce the fact that all the parameters are non-null (which by itself is fine too).
However, as is this means one has to write things like:

```java
var styleDescription = LabelStyleDescription.newLabelStyleDescription()
                                            .colorProvider(variableManager -> "#051e37")
                                            .fontSizeProvider(variableManager -> 16)
                                            .boldProvider(variableManager -> false)
                                            .italicProvider(variableManager -> false)
                                            .underlineProvider(variableManager -> false)
                                            .strikeThroughProvider(variableManager -> false)
                                            .iconURLProvider(variableManager -> "")
                                            .build();
```

I shouldn't have to explicitly specify that I do not want may label to be "strike through" at the risk of getting an NPE if I forget this attribute I do not care about.

Most attributes here should have some sensible defaults so that I only need to override the attributes I care about:

```java
var styleDescription = LabelStyleDescription.newLabelStyleDescription()
                                            .colorProvider(variableManager -> "#051e37")
                                            .fontSizeProvider(variableManager -> 16)
                                            .build();
```

Note that this is not just a convenience. Using the current rules, as soon as we add some new attribute, say the font name here, all existing code, including in already defined and deployed modelers, becomes broken and will throw an NPE because they have not specified an explicit value for an attribute which did not even exist when they were written.

If we really want to leave the existing `LabelStyleDescription.newLabelStyleDescription()` (I don't really see why leave this "trap" to users of the API), the defaults could be limited to a new method:

```java
public static Builder newLabelStyleDescriptionWithDefaults() {
    return new Builder().colorProvider(variableManager -> "#6A6C6E")
                        .fontSizeProvider(variableManager -> 14)
                        .boldProvider(variableManager -> false)
                        .italicProvider(variableManager -> false)
                        .underlineProvider(variableManager -> false)
                        .strikeThroughProvider(variableManager -> false)
                        .iconURLProvider(variableManager -> "");
}
```


_Optional_: when it makes sense, some builder methods could be overloaded with variants or alternative methods without the `Provider` suffix which take a constant so that I don't have to write a lambda:

```java
var styleDescription = LabelStyleDescription.newLabelStyleDescription()
                                            .colorProvider("#051e37")
                                            .fontSizeProvider(16)
                                            .build();
```

or shorter and more exact (as the constants are not "providers" anymore):

```java
var styleDescription = LabelStyleDescription.newLabelStyleDescription().color("#051e37").fontSize(16).build();
```

title: NA
body: Note that the example code uses `LabelStyleDescription`, but the issue is more general and applies to other builders and attributes.

> Note that this is not just a convenience. Using the current rules, as soon as we add some new attribute, say the font name here, all existing code, including in already defined and deployed modelers, becomes broken and will throw an NPE because they have not specified an explicit value for an attribute which did not even exist when they were written.

This is not theoretical: this happened at least once when we added support for direct edit on edges. The `ViewConverter` code was not updated, eveything compiled but any attempt to create an edge description in a dynamic studio caused an NPE. See [the fix](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/commit/4db91313d078e6d82b3017dd661a1749cec53941).

title: EditingContextEventProcessors are never released
body:
`IEditingContextEventProcessor` are allocated the first time an input event is sent to a particular editing context (by id), which typically happens when a user first opens a projet. They are never released afterwards, even if no user is currently working on the corresponding project/editing context and has not been for a while.

`EditingContextEventProcessor` holds a reference to the `IEditingContext`, which in turn references the whole contents of the project (documents, e.g. an EMF ResourceSet, but also all diagrams and other representations via their `IRepresentationEventProcessor`).

body:

title: Improve time precision using System.nanoTime() instead of currentTimeMillis()
Potential NPE in Edge.toString()
body:
In `org.eclipse.sirius.web.diagrams.Edge`, the `toString()` method assumes that all 3 potential labels are non-null, but the `Edge.Builder.build()` method does not enforce this constraint for labels (as opossed to all the other fields).

The `get*Label()` methods lack the `@GraphQLNonNull` annotation, so clearly the fact that these can be absent is by design, and the bug is not in `Edge.Builder.build()` but in `toString()`.

title: NA
body: Initially reported as part of eclipse-sirius/sirius-components#1794.

title: NA
body: Fixed by 10eb8c845b53fef222e93b5efa5446610fa113a7

title: EdgeRequestor wrongly assumes that all edges have different targetObjectIds
body:
In `org.eclipse.sirius.web.diagrams.components.EdgesRequestor`, we build a map for edges indexeds by `Edge.getTargetObjectId`, but this fails when multiple edges have the same targetObjectId, which is a completely normal situation.

This can cause an `IllegalStateException` thrown in `Collectors.duplicateKeyException(Collectors.java:133)`, see https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/issues/1794 (in that ticket the exception is hidden by another bug, #274).

title: NA
Properties view does not take custom EDataType in consideration
body:
The various `DescriptionProviders` in `org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.compatibility.properties` have predicates which are too strong. For example `EStringIfDescriptionProvider` will only match `EAttributes` which are exactly typed `EString`, but ignore the ones which use a custom `EDataType` which maps (like `EString`) onto `java.lang.String`.

As an example, trying to display properties views on a Sirius Desktop VSM does not show all the intepreted expressions, as those are typed with the `InterpretedExpression [java.lang.String]` data type defined in `viewpoint.ecore`.

The same is true for booleans (the test `eAttribute.getEType().equals(EcorePackage.Literals.EBOOLEAN)` is too strict), and in `NumberIfDescriptionProvider`, where `eAttribute.getEType().equals(this.eDataType)` should also consider the case where `eAttribute.getEType().getInstanceClassName().equals(this.eDataType.getInstanceClassName())`.

title: Some tests are ignored (and broken) since the move to Spring Boot 2.4.0
body:
Since we moved to Spring Boot 2.4.0 (in 3de3c795396e92db1c65596bb5a5d16a0deec41c), the tests in some of our Maven modules are no longer detected and run, and some of those have now KO without anyone noticing.

This is caused by Spring Boot 2.4.0 removing support for JUnit 4 runners by default, see https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.4-Release-Notes#junit-5s-vintage-engine-removed-from-spring-boot-starter-test. We did not add the "vintage" runner dependency, so JUnit 5 does not see our JUnit 4 style tests.

The projects impacted are:
```
sirius-web-emf/pom.xml
sirius-web-persistence/pom.xml
sirius-web-spring-graphql/pom.xml
sirius-web-spring/pom.xml
sirius-web-test-diagrams-only-application/pom.xml
sirius-web-test-sample-application/pom.xml
```

Once the dependency is added back, the tests are correctly found and executed, but there are test failures that we did not notice in `sirius-web-emf` and `sirius-web-persistence`.

### Expected behavior
The layout of an element is be updated after  a move, a create action in a diagram, via a tool, a resizing action. The element might be overlapped by other elements.

The purpose is to detect these overlaps and move the different elements accordingly.

This overlap might be intentional, it should be possible to authorize this case if needed.

title: Let end users move contained elements
body:
Today, when an element is moved in its container, it is blocked at its borders.
The purpose is to allow the move of an element to another container and manage the semantic consequences.

It should thus be possible to move a child element from one container to another. This should work with free from layouted nodes and list layouted nodes. It should also allow moving border nodes from one node to another.

body: Beside the authorization issue, note that the frontend can not reliably predict the actual effect of the edition tool on the future value of the label. The tool executed on the backend can perform any arbitrary modification of the model, and the expression used to compute the label's value can itself to perform arbitrary computations on the new state of the model.

title: How to customize the metamodel?
body:
Hey 🙂 I'm excited to see this project, as I have been looking for a way to create a web-based diagram editor.

I wanted to use it, but I have trouble figuring out how I could customize the metamodel. I know I would have to create the `ecore` and `genmodel` files using Obeo Designer, but what then? How do I tell sirius-web to use the new model?

So far in the source code I have only found a path to an `odesign` file (https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/4ce40bc68e50d1a0704804b189ab6f3b134612a7/backend/sirius-web-sample-application/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/sample/configuration/SampleSiriusConfiguration.java#L30) and the `SampleEMFConfiguration` (https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/4ce40bc68e50d1a0704804b189ab6f3b134612a7/backend/sirius-web-sample-application/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/sample/configuration/SampleEMFConfiguration.java) that (if I'm not mistaken) instructs sirius-component's backend to use that generated code.

Could you help me out with a list of steps describing how I could go about changing the metamodel used by sirius-web?

title: NA
body:
Hi,

Currently the only way to add support for a new business domain is to define it using a "classical" EMF-based metamodel, generated from the Eclipse-based EMF tooling. Once you have it, you need to register the corresponding EMF `EPackage` and `AdapterFactory`, as you correctly guessed.

Then to create an actual modeler to edit instances of this domain you could define your own diagram definition in plain Java, but the current APIs we offer are rather low-level so this is the "hard core mode". The easiest way for now is to use Sirius Desktop to create the modeler definition. It will produce a `.odesign` file which, in most simple cases, is a self-contained definition of your diagram. This is the file you then need to reference in the configuration above.

In short, for the time being to create your own modeler on your own custom domain the easiest way it to get a working version on Sirius Desktop (using the tooling available in Obeo Designer CE for example) and then to plug that in Sirius Web. https://github.com/ObeoNetwork/Flow-Designer/, which we use in the sample Sirius Web application is a good example of that. It existed before, was made with/for Sirius Desktop, but with minimal adaptations it can be used inside Sirius Web.

If you are completely new to the Eclipse/EMF world, we have tutorials [here](https://wiki.eclipse.org/Sirius/Tutorials) which start from scratch with [the definition of the domain model](https://wiki.eclipse.org/Sirius/Tutorials/DomainModelTutorial) up to the build and distribution of a Sirius Desktop-based modeler (which you can then use in Sirius Web like the sample application uses the Flow modeler).

We hope to streamline all of these steps in the near future, the end goal being to be able to create and use your own modeler from scratch without leaving your browser, so stay tuned!

title: NA

I'll keep the issue open in case more questions pop up, if that's not a problem

By the way, do you think it would be useful to update the README with some information on how to change the metamodel (i.e. the description you provided)? I could try to submit a PR that adds it

title: NA
body:
I've managed to create a metamodel and got it working with sirus-web - it looks great so far.

I do have one question that I can't figure out, though. It's not strictly related to sirus-web, but I don't know where else to ask. Since it's not strictly related to sirius-web, I don't want to open a new issue to avoid polluting the issue tracker.

I can't get imports to be resolved correctly in Java files inside model packages when using VSCode or Neovim (both use https://github.com/eclipse/eclipse.jdt.ls under the hood).

<details>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136439769-67279b72-8dbb-47c5-a504-dc23d436fe0c.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136440146-e04ed5cc-082d-4038-9366-62ce6c5ca532.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136439993-b1c021c6-bc42-44fb-abcd-4e1140099026.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136440027-218fb72e-19ba-4d98-bd69-e48bf7ae949d.png)

</details>

Looks like VSCode can handle a bit better, as it resolves imports from other model packages and only fails to resolve external ones (from `org.eclipse`). Neovim fails to resolve either of those.

They are resolved fine and everything seems to be working when opening those files with Obeo Designer.

<details>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136440316-3daa23a8-d174-4b8e-88d6-06a7fc599d64.png)

</details>

There are also no errors when packaging those modules with Maven (with Tycho).

<details>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136440431-c34ab8e3-90f1-4cd5-8586-f86dad516ab5.png)

</details>

There are (almost) no problems with imports when opening regular projects, e.g. `sirius-web-sample-application` from this repository:

<details>

VSCode fares well
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136440900-6316f6ff-74ee-42c2-bd80-fba4c9a80d7d.png)

Neovim has some problems, but works for the most part
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/136441703-1360af86-e515-4222-8f1b-b2576845157d.png)

</details>


So, looks like the problems are only when opening model projects (`eclipse-plugin` `packaging` in `pom.xml`)

The problem occurs both in the model that I have created (https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/tree/main/packages/model) as well as when I opened https://github.com/ObeoNetwork/Flow-Designer with Neovim or VSCode.

I found very little information online about this exact case. I have tried various Tycho settings, removing `.classpath` files, adding `dependency` in `pom.xml`s between packages, none of it worked.

How do I get https://github.com/eclipse/eclipse.jdt.ls to correctly resolve imports and dependencies in Java files inside model packages? If you're working in VSCode and have only VSCode-related tips, that works too.

Let me know if you'd prefer me to create a separate issue or have suggestions where I should post this problem.

title: NA
body:
Hi.

The projects in Flow-Designer are not plain/classical Java projects, but Eclipse Plug-in Projects. 

Tycho and Obeo Designer know about this kind of projects and know where to look for their dependencies and how to resolve them to build a build-path/classpath: the dependencies are declared in the OSGi `META-INF/MANIFEST.MF`, and will be resolved from the Target Platform definition which refers to p2 repositories where to find the OSGi bundles (JARs) required.

VS Code, NeoVim or any other IDE which is not aware of this type of project will not find the dependencies. If it knows about Maven it will look inside the `pom.xml` files, but the dependencies are not declared there.

I don't think any non Eclipse-based IDE knows how to deal with the specifics of Eclipse Plug-in Projects (VS Code uses `eclipse.jdt.ls` which indeed comes from Eclipse, but is a lower-level component and does not know about these).

[Spring Tool Suite for Eclipse](https://spring.io/tools) is based on Eclipse, and provided you install the Eclipse PDE (Plug-in Developement Environment, not sure if it's installed by default) you can have a single IDE which can deal with both plain Maven projects (through M2E) and Eclipse Plug-ins (through PDE).

Otherwise you'll need to explicitly declare the project dependencies in the `pom.xml`, this needs finding Maven repos where they are available (which is not always easy, as projects from the Eclipse world tend to publish to p2 repos only).

EMF itself is available in Maven Central, and https://repo.eclipse.org/ contains others. In particular the Sirius Desktop JARs that Sirius Web depends on are obtained from there. See https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/master/backend/sirius-web-compatibility/pom.xml#L43 and the dependencies starting at https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/master/backend/sirius-web-compatibility/pom.xml#L143.

title: NA
body: Thank you for a detailed response and all the resources. It looks like I will be better off using Obeo Designer for modifying the source code of the metamodel, and use my preferred IDEs for other projects. It is all clear to me now and I am finally sure that it's not my IDE being misconfigured.
