title: Readonly references can be changed
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** :
- other: 0.4.12
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : 
- Ubuntu 20.04 LTS

### Summary

References that are marked as _Readonly_ in the model's Generation tab still can be changed in Sirius Web.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140173125-09fe6a7d-6cb4-4c3d-adbc-e564395bb237.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140173144-407f8dd7-14ae-4f97-9689-d87c59afb416.png)

Making the property not _changeable_ breaks the deserialization of the model, so it's not possible.

Probably related to https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/issues/813

### Steps to reproduce

1. In the Generation tab in Sirius Desktop, mark a reference as readonly
2. Edit it in Sirius Web

### Expected behavior

The field is `readonly`/`disabled`.

### Actual behavior

The field is editable.

### Sirius Desktop compatibility

The property cannot be changed in Sirius Desktop's _Semantic_ tab:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140173423-1ea9f322-f6f6-4525-bed2-ed2b7bfac38a.png)

But it can be changed in the _Main_ tab:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140173445-3b008e3c-6112-4963-8bd5-a2fecae1f308.png)

title: Support dialog model operations
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

When a tool in the odesign file has dialog that lets the user perform an action with greater convenience, it would be great to also render the same dialog in Sirius Web.

My tool for creating a new node has a dialog inside

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140173853-e743de2d-e1d2-4472-b5f7-a3c432d53854.png)

It works well in Sirius Desktop.

When trying to invoke that tool in Sirius Web, I get the following errors shown in the browser

> Invalid input type, "InvokeNodeToolOnDiagramInput" has been received while "InvokeNodeToolOnDiagramInput" was expected

Server logs show:

```sh
e.s.w.e.c.m.ModelOperationHandlerSwitch : The model operation DialogModelOperationImpl is not currently supported
```

### Cuttings backs

No clue what to write here.

### Potential side effects

The dialogs API seems quite robust, so supporting it can be tricky.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Alternatively, instead of using the dialogs from the odesign file, we could add dialogs by writing React components in the frontend application. They would not be metamodel-specific, though.

title: Semantic model validation rule results are not shown
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** :
- other: 0.4.12
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : 
- Ubuntu 20.04 LTS

### Summary

Results of semantic model validation rules defined in the odesign file are not shown in Sirius Web.

I created a couple of semantic validation rules in the odesign file:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140175207-ab120a1c-1247-4cef-82bb-08caee1de2a0.png)

When they are violated, the errors are shown in Sirius Desktop:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140175242-0b3fc3f1-3edd-4f69-8be5-f2ceda2bcf4b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140175255-55a77a22-bede-4a43-a5cf-ed9f949c7998.png)

But the list of validations is empty in Sirius Web:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/140175289-4ab5fc89-99f4-4606-837a-2f33a383811c.png)

Even a semantic validation rule that is always aql:false is not shown in Sirius Web, and is always visible in Sirius Desktop.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add a semantic validation rule in the odesign file
2. Make the rule fail in Sirius Web

### Expected behavior

There is a diagnostic shown for that semantic validation rule.

### Actual behavior

There are no messages from that semantic validation rule. It is as if the rule was not picked up by Sirius Web at all.

title: Improve typing of the frontend
body: In order to prepare for the integration of some large changes, better type definition would be helpful to ensure the stability of the code.

title: NA
body: Part of this work has been done in this milestone but I'll leave this issue open since it's an ongoing work

title: Add an ADR about a more structured selection
How can we debug sirius components?
body: How can I debug this library continuous?   Which like that I run the sample application sirius web and modify the sirius components code. Then refresh to make those changes take effect.

title: NA
body:
Hi,

You can debug the code of the backend of Sirius Components by having it in your workspace with the backend of Sirius Web and launching all the server at once. For the frontend, we are relying on [Yalc](https://www.npmjs.com/package/yalc) to consume a locally built version of Sirius Components. We change Sirius Components, build it and publish it locally on Yalc and then refresh Sirius Web.

We could probably improve this workflow to run both parts of the frontend code at once but we did not have the time to explore such improvements for now.

title: NA
body: Really thanks.

title: Add delete from diagram generic tool in diagrams
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

Today, all diagram elements have a delete tool. This tool delete the element from the diagram and also from the model.
For a specific mapping, if a delete element tool has been defined in the odesign, then the behavior of the delete element tool is called instead of the generic delete. 

The goal is to have two generic delete tools: one for the graphical deletion (only on unsynchronized mappings) and one for the model deletion.
If a delete element tool has been defined in the odesign for a mapping, then the generic delete tools are not available anymore. Only the specific delete element tool is available.

title: Support custom style
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

Node  style can be customized by giving a style ID.

### Cuttings backs

...

### Potential side effects

no

### Describe alternatives you've considered


The default style can't meet the demand, It would be flexible to allow define the custom style ID in VSM and provide implement in frontend.

title: NA
body: The style needs to be handled by the backend in order to compute the layout of the diagram. So we can add new styles but we can't delegate everything to the frontend to do anything it want. Today, it is possible for someone to compute the SVG of a diagram fully server side since we have all the information for that (we don't provide that right now but we have everything to do it, it's not very complicated).

title: NA
body:
I think it's OK to compute the layout in server , but what if a figure contains the dynamic content will be updated by a model's property?
For example:
A model has a color property , the figure's color will follow the property's change.
A model has a number property that will change the amount of the border nodes , and the figure will display this number to indicate that how many border nodes the current node have.

title: NA
body: We already support computed styles. In our flow sample, the appearance of the data source is computed from their name (try Wifi or Radar). In a similar fashion, we have example where the size of the rectangle is computed from a property with the type integer.

title: NA
body: What if I want to make the fan spin faster when I change the speed property in flow example? (May I need to regenerate the svg),  I can use the conditional style to handle the limited number of enum values,  but it can't handle a random value like speed value from 1 to 100000 etc.

title: NA
body:
Technically, you can create a style computed from some properties, for example using `NodeDescription#getStyleProvider()` you could say that the style is an `ImageNodeStyle` with the URL `fan.svg?speed=10` or `fan.svg?speed=10000` (this can be computed from the properties of the object). From that, when you will need to provide the fan image using a regular Spring Controller, you can create / customize it programmatically.

Sirius Components allows that but Sirius Web does not offer the way to do it. In Sirius Web, we would need to allow specifiers to provide an image for the requested path (regardless of how the image is retrieved / created) in the `ImageController`. Right now, Sirius Web will only look for the image in the class path (`new ClassPathResource(imagePath)`) so Sirius Web expects that the image is a static resource.

title: NA
body: I think this maybe  be a good solution , thanks.

title: Contribute some technical documentation
body: I will contribute some technical documentation in order to describe the philosophy of Sirius Components and how it can be used.

I suspect it has something to do with the pins (border nodes) appearing outside of the `UnitCall` (the white node). After moving the pins just slightly, the creation works mostly fine:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/141341113-e761225d-fcbc-40dd-932c-857c84b57982.mp4

But it is not very reliable. As you can see at the end of the video, the problem happened even though I moved the border nodes.

It would be nice if the exception did not happen. Perhaps I am doing something wrong in https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/blob/main/backend/sirius-web-services/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/services/unitcalls/CreateUnitCallEventHandler.java - let me know if that is the case and I can fix it on my end.


### Steps to reproduce

1. Add multiple objects programmatically (probably multiple times)

I know it may be hard to reproduce using a fresh instance of Sirius Web. You can use my fork (https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web) if you want - sending the following mutation multiple times in a row always reproduces the error (at least as far as I checked):

<details>

```graphql
mutation {
  createUnitCall(input: {
    	id: "cfcce8ef-47e3-4f5e-9ecc-847deba46219",
    	rootObjectId:"9e778a79-c5bb-484d-9867-86d4caddec18",
      editingContextId: "a7fdb460-e342-42a6-924e-d31cbb53db69",
    unitRelease:{
      id: "110f65c2-3fc6-411c-9ded-8c8cf96db52d",
      name: "Bounding Labels",
      version: "0.11",
      pins: [
        {
          id: "c915d7a5-dec5-4b60-9fdb-00eed6591cc4",
          name:"Input",
          binding:REQUIRED,
          tokenMultiplicity: SINGLE,
          dataMultiplicity: SINGLE
        },
        {
          id: "76c05ac4-4b34-4053-97e5-8d65748d1485",
          name:"Output",
          binding: PROVIDED,
          tokenMultiplicity: SINGLE,
          dataMultiplicity: SINGLE
        }
      ]
    }
  }) {
    __typename
    ... on CreateUnitCallSuccessPayload {
      id
      createdUnitCall {
        id
        kind
        label
      }
    }
  }
}
```

Make sure to change the inputs:
* `rootObjectId` to the ID of the root object in the model (`ComputationApplicationRelease`)
* `editingContextId`

</details>

You can get the JAR from https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/actions/runs/1449876408. It is a drop-in replacement for the one from the https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web repository - it will use the same database credentials and will expose the same port.

### Expected behavior

Objects are created and shown on the diagram without any exceptions.

### Actual behavior

There is an exception and the diagram (and the model) stop being functional - the diagram cannot be displayed after that exception.

The only thing that helps to show the diagram again is removing all objects from the model and starting from scratch - so basically, the moment the exception happens, the model is no longer usable.

title: Expose all lower-level frontend components
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

I want to customize the `Workbench` component by adding new panels to it. I see it does not accept any props (it is suggested in https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/issues/693), thus, the way for me to customize it would be to copy the code to my project and edit it manually. However, this can be problematic, because not all components are accessible to consumers of the library. [`index.ts`](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/master/frontend/src/index.ts) exports a limited set of components. Accessing other components individually is not possible.

For example, if I wanted to reuse the `RightSite` component in the `Workbench` copied to my repository, I would like to do:

```ts
import { RightSite } from '@eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/build/workbench/RightSite';
```

but, at the moment, the `build` directory bundles everything into `index.js` / `index.es.js`.

Thus would probably require modifying rollup's `output` configurations:

https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/0fa68a46463e41d17853ce3a04f614c0bd9bedec/frontend/rollup.config.js#L25-L35

[`output.preserveModules`](https://rollupjs.org/guide/en/#outputpreservemodules) looks like the option to use here, probably combined with [`output.entryFileNames`](https://rollupjs.org/guide/en/#outputentryfilenames) to use different extensions for ES and CJS modules.

### Cuttings backs

N/A

### Potential side effects

1. Consumers of the frontend package will need to watch out for breaking changes.
2. Consumers' bundler will do more work (depending on the approach - if the main `index.js` does not contain bundled code, but only exports other components)


### Describe alternatives you've considered

There is https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/issues/693 already reported, but, in my view, exposing all components will be simpler and give more control to the consumers of the library.,

title: NA
body:
We have started with everything exported and we changed our mind. This has been done on purpose and we will remove other low level components that are currently exported. We are making tons of changes all the time and we break tons of things everywhere each time. There's 15 to 30 components that have been in the process of being deleted over the past few months but are still here (pretty much everything in `frontend/src/core` to get started). In order to provide a relatively stable developer experience to consumers of Sirius Components we have tried over the past few months to define what our API is and to ensure a minimum amount of changes to said API. This is why we have decided not to export everything but to make sure that what we are exporting stay *quite* stable.

With that in mind, if you want some API evolution (to customize the workbench for example), you can open an issue on this topic or try contributing an ADR (or some code) on such evolution.

title: NA
body: Thank you for the response. I understand the approach you are taking. I will see what is possible with the current API first

title: NA
body:
I've done some investigation and it looks like I can mostly recreate the `Workbench` component myself in Sirius Web out of the exposed components. The only 3 components that I would need, but are not exposed, are:

- `OnboardArea`
- `Panels` (from `core/`)
- `ValidationWebSocketContainer`

I can recreate `Panels` and `ValidationWebSocketContainer` easily myself by copy-pasting the code, but `OnboardArea` is tricky. The components that `OnboardArea` uses (https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/ab8097c6c3593f10fdd16f9212762624a3639ccc/frontend/src/onboarding/OnboardArea.tsx#L93-L106
) are also not exposed.

Is it intended that these 3 components (`Panels`, `ValidationWebSocketContainer`, and `OnboardArea`) are not exposed publicly?

title: Component names are minified
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** :
- other: 0.5.3
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : 
- Ubuntu 20.04 LTS

### Screenshots

Names of components imported from this library are minified

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/141438909-410a50e5-d6ca-4f65-955d-9727ca2e1460.png)

which makes inspecting them and navigating in the React DevTools in a Sirius Web application more difficult.

Material UI component names are not minified, which you can see on the screenshot. As a result, it is much easier to see the purpose of each component.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/141439337-e3ba0ceb-c147-4d9e-9cc3-58c68769abf2.png)

Compare that with a component from this repository:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/141439530-9fe50037-ee49-4c1f-9464-4faf85fea8ce.png)

https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/issues/4081 contains some possible solutions.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open React Devtools in Sirus Web
2. Navigate to a components from `sirius-components`

### Expected behavior

The original, unminified name is shown.

### Actual behavior

A minified name is shown.

title: NA
body:
On the `sirius-components` side this is handled by `rollup-plugin-terser`. The alternative Rollup config in `rollup-dev.config.js` (used by `npm run build:dev`) bypasses `terser` completely, which might be too extreme.

A quick test with `terser({ mangle: false })` in `rollup.config.js` instead of just `terser()` seems to fix the issue. I'm not sure we want this in the production build?

Anyway, when developing I usually use `npm run build:dev` as it does not have this issue and is faster (to build).

title: NA
body:
Sure, an easy workaround for me would be to clone `sirius-components` locally, build it myself and then use my local version to develop an application in the sirius-web fork.

> Anyway, when developing I usually use `npm run build:dev` as it does not have this issue and is faster (to build).

I would be worried this assumes engineers working on Sirius Web forks are expected to work with a locally-built development build of `sirius-components` if they want to see component names.

---

The main point I wanted to make here is that this is not ideal for a components library (and IMO `sirius-components` is a component library, with `sirius-web` being a consumer of it) because it makes consuming it while developing an application based on Sirius Web more difficult.



In my view, an easy solution here would be adding `displayName` to publicly exposed React components (those that are exported in the main `index.ts`). This way the public API is well named. The internals can remain unnamed.

This is a minor issue for me and I can work around it. Being one of the first consumers of Sirius Web (or so I think, looking at the list of forks) I wanted to report issues with the development experience I am facing so we can improve it for everyone

title: NA
body: @pcdavid we should try to see if we could simply minify Sirius Components code in the Sirius Web build or deliver a minified and a non minified version and pick the proper one in the development vs production environment of Sirius Web.

title: Moving a selection of a Node and a child node make the child node moving faster
body:
### Screenshots

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7371042/142221569-931d0498-ef14-45a8-8a35-0ac56ddfc3f1.mp4

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Robot Flow model
2. Create a Topography diagram on System
3. Select `Central_Unit` and `Motion_Engine` using _CTRL_ or _CMD_
4. Move one of the elements

### Expected behavior

The `Motion_Engine` should not move inside its container like other nodes.

### Actual behavior

The `Motion_Engine` is moving inside its container while the container is being moved.

title: The position of the droped element is not where it should be
body:
### Screenshots

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7371042/142249391-d05b2ced-e081-46c2-9d25-d1ed6e8a465a.mp4

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a flow model
2. Create an unsynchronized diagram on System
3. Drag and Drop `Central_Unit` from the explorer to the diagram

### Expected behavior

The node that represents `Central_Unit` should be positioned where the drop has been made.
The node size should well proportioned.

### Actual behavior

The node that represents `Central_Unit` is not at the drop position.
The node size is wider than expected.

title: NA
body: After analysis, it comes from the incremental layout algorithm which tries to position contained nodes first,  so the drop position is used to calculate the position of the first `Central_Unit` child. Moreover, the incremental layout algorithm considers the child's position is relative to its parent and thus, making the `Central_Unit` node being wider as far as the drop position is far from the diagram origin point.

title: CreateView depending on others CreateView are not supported
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

CreateView have a "variable name" attribute. If you want to define a CreateView depending on another CreateView (in https://github.com/ObeoNetwork/Flow-Designer/blob/ocp/plugins/fr.obeo.dsl.designer.sample.flow.design/description/flow.odesign#L979 fro example), you cannot do it because the "variable name" defined in the first CreateView is not supported in the sirius-web-emf project (see org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.compatibility.modeloperations.CreateViewOperationHandler#handle method).
The problem seems have deep impacts because the CreateView operations are all executed on diagram refresh and not in the CreateViewOperationHandler#handle method.

title: NA
body:
I am not 100% sure that I understand the issue but the refresh strategy of Sirius Components' diagrams is indeed very different from Sirius Desktop's ones. From what I understand, we would need a way to dynamically compute `ViewCreationRequest` in the refresh and let the compatibility layer provide how.

I don't think that it's that difficult to make but it would require a very precise ADR in order to find out how.

title: Obsolete/invalid view instances are kept in the database but are unusable
body:
### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a diagram definition (with a domain) in a studio project **S**
2. Create an instance of the diagram (with an instance of the domain) in an instance project **I**
3. Close project **I**
4. In project **S**, remove the diagram definition
5. Reopen project **I**: the diagram appears in the explorer but when opening it it's empty and says it does not exist

### Expected behavior

- the obsolete diagram should not appear
- it should not cause any visible error
- it should be removed from the database (otherwise it will stay there forever)

### Analysis

At first glance, the `Representation.deleteDanglingRepresentations` SQL query should also consider validating `Representation.descriptionId` (the field is not currently directly exposed in the DB Schema, but it will be when eclipse-sirius/sirius-components#699 is fixed).

title: Switch to Sirius Desktop 6.6.0 when it is released
body:
We are [currently](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/master/backend/sirius-web-compatibility/pom.xml#L31) using Sirius Desktop version 6.5.1 for the compatibility layer.

[Sirius Desktop 6.6.0](https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/modeling.sirius/releases/6.6.0) should be released soon. I don't think the changes in that version should impact us (positively or negatively), but we should still plan the switch in order to stay current and consistent.

Note that version 7.0 of Sirius Desktop, which should be release in Q1 2022 will have more impacting changes.

title: NA
body: Are there any dependency change in Sirius 6.6.0 that we need to deal with? New version of AQL, update in the range of Ecore used, additional dependency?

title: NA
body: No dependency change at all between 6.5.1 and 6.6.0.

title: NA
body: [Sirius Desktop 6.6.0](https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/modeling.sirius/releases/6.6.0) was officially released last friday.

title: Explain how to authenticate WebSocket connections
body:
I am using Sirius Web to build a diagram editor (see my fork: https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web). I have gotten to a point that I want to enable authentication and authorize users so they only see projects they own. I am using JWT-based authentication, but I don't think that should matter.

I have successfully added authentication to regular REST endpoints, as well as the GraphQL query/mutation endpoint (`/api/graphql`). I have trouble adding authentication to WebSocket connections (GraphQL subscriptions using the `/subscriptions`) endpoint.

So far I found that the `Authorization` header (or any other custom header, for that matter) is not passed when using WebSockets ([source](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4361173/http-headers-in-websockets-client-api/41521871)). WebSocket authorization has to be done in other ways, usually through sending the authentication information in one of the initial messages.

This leads me to believe that authenticating WebSocket connections is at the moment not possible without modifications to `sirius-components`. To be concrete, from what I found I would either need to:

1. Register a `HandshakeInterceptor` for the `WebSocketHandlerRegistration` in https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/ab8097c6c3593f10fdd16f9212762624a3639ccc/backend/sirius-web-spring-graphql/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/spring/graphql/configuration/WebSocketConfiguration.java#L63-L64 and somehow set the `Principal` there. Some related StackOverflow questions on this
    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28567146/how-to-set-a-principal-within-a-handshakeinterceptor
    * https://stackoverflow.com/a/27765688/4874344

    The problem here is that custom headers are not sent by browsers in WebSocket connections, so the HTTP connection itself will be void of any authentication data, so the interceptor won't be able to set anything. The authentication data would come in a subsequent WebSocket message, but that's already past the interceptor's job.

2. Extract the `Authorization` token from the payload sent in the `connection_init` initial WebSocket message, but that happens in `GraphQLWebSocketHandler`, which I believe I cannot modify from Sirius Web: https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/ab8097c6c3593f10fdd16f9212762624a3639ccc/backend/sirius-web-spring-graphql/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/spring/graphql/ws/GraphQLWebSocketHandler.java#L243-L256

    This would seem like the most correct solution.

From what I could tell, in Sirius Web the WebSocket connections work fine due to [the `SiriusWebAuthenticationFilter`](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/master/backend/sirius-web-sample-application/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/sample/filters/SiriusWebAuthenticationFilter.java), which appends `Authorization` headers to **all** requests (both regular HTTP API requests **and** WebSocket connections). This seems like a hack that hides the fact that WebSocket requests **cannot** have such headers because browsers just don't send them ([source](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4361173/http-headers-in-websockets-client-api/41521871)). I expect that if we removed `SiriusWebAuthenticationFilter` and instead attached the `Authorization` header to all API requests, the problem with WebSocket connections missing authentication information would be surfaced.

If it is possible at the moment to authenticate WebSocket connections and I have missed something, let me know. If not, I would appreciate making the changes to allow passing authentication data to those connections

My authentication-related work is generally described https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/issues/96 (see https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/issues/96#issuecomment-980572837 for a description of the problem) and implemented so far in https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/pull/97.
You can use the JAR built in CI (https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/actions/runs/1510579015) if you want to test it yourselves.

title: NA
body:
I have used the current `master` of Sirius Web and moved the `Authorization` header to the frontend. See https://github.com/Gelio/sirius-web/commit/27d862c1796546ca64dc2adeb577991e26a114ec

GraphQL queries and mutations now correctly expect the header to be sent via the frontend and result in 401 errors if the header is not present. GraphQL subscriptions seem to work without any headers. This is not what I observed on https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/pull/97 where I was getting `connection_error` responses via WebSocket:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/143765709-684d95fb-e68b-42d5-be6f-8eeb7a4f8e47.png)

Presumably this is because on my branch with JWT authentication I removed https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/0866885f5ed3c3f4ee758c756d4c25c2d7f8fb94/backend/sirius-web-sample-application/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/sample/configuration/SpringWebSecurityConfiguration.java#L52

and thus, there is likely no `principal` set in https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/ab8097c6c3593f10fdd16f9212762624a3639ccc/backend/sirius-web-spring-graphql/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/spring/graphql/ws/GraphQLWebSocketHandler.java#L244-L245 which results in the errors I am seeing on my branch.

This does not solve the problem, because I want to use JWT-based authentication.

title: NA
body:
I managed to find a workaround that lets me use GraphQL subscriptions without requiring any authentication information. See https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/pull/97/commits/2b0742e22adccb3144784003ea35bb39f756f5bb

The workaround is to always supply the `Authorization` `principal` for the `/subscriptions` GraphQL endpoint.

This is flawed because there is no authentication/authorization for that endpoint and anyone can get read-only access to any model via GraphQL subscriptions.

This makes my priority for fixing this issue lower, but I would still like to have JWT authentication enabled for GraphQL subscriptions too.

title: NA
body: With this WebSocket workaround (hardcoding an `Authorization` used for WebSockets), I faced a roadblock when trying to restrict access to projects based on username. See https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/pull/111/commits/fad18f5e6bc5a3b463a29c0ea8498ca83f573eb6. I could restrict access for GraphQL queries, so only projects owned by the current user are shown, but for GraphQL subscriptions when I added the `username` check to the https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/blob/fad18f5e6bc5a3b463a29c0ea8498ca83f573eb6/backend/sirius-web-persistence/src/main/resources/db/sirius-web-named-queries.properties#L6 (which is used in https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/blob/fad18f5e6bc5a3b463a29c0ea8498ca83f573eb6/backend/sirius-web-services/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/services/editingcontext/EditingContextSearchService.java#L92-L96) query since I am using a hardcoded username in my workaround, the query always returned 0 elements.

title: NA
body:
Hi,

> This leads me to believe that authenticating WebSocket connections is at the moment not possible without modifications to sirius-components. 

There are a couple of proprietary product which integrate the GraphQLWebSocketHandler with an authentication system without issues. Since they are proprietary solutions, I cannot share their code source but here are a couple comments.

> From what I could tell, in Sirius Web the WebSocket connections work fine due to the SiriusWebAuthenticationFilter, which appends Authorization headers to all requests (both regular HTTP API requests and WebSocket connections). This seems like a hack that hides the fact that WebSocket requests cannot have such headers because browsers just don't send them (source).

The GraphQL API over WebSocket works in Sirius Web only because of the SiriusWebAuthenticationFilter (overwise it would fail since we wouldn't have any principal as you have noticed). This class is a big hack that I have created quite quickly to solve this simple issue.

Sirius Components needs to be Spring Security aware and it needs to manipulate Principal instances at some locations. Honestly, I'm quite convinced that we could even remove that requirement entirely and it would be a great improvement. Yet at the same time, Sirius Web will not try to cover the topic of authentication and authorization. My goal was to quickly to have an Authentication instance in all use cases without having to think about it. I haven't found the time to go back and look at this old hack to see how I could improve it or even remove it entirely to replace it with a more simple Spring Security configuration.

Since Sirius Components will need a Principal, we have made it a requirement at the very top of the GraphQLWebSocketHandler instead of discovering that something is missing deep down below (it also comes from the fact that we used to do stuff with this principal there but that part of the code has been removed since it was useless anyway).

That being said, the core part of your question remain, how is this principal given to the WebSocket connection to work with the current user afterwards? As I said, I can't share proprietary code here but in some projects that I have manipulated that is just plainly handled by Spring Security itself. There's no magic, there's nothing special.

https://docs.spring.io/spring-security/site/docs/5.0.7.RELEASE/reference/html/websocket.html#websocket-authentication

> 24.2 WebSocket Authentication
> WebSockets reuse the same authentication information that is found in the HTTP request when the WebSocket connection was made. This means that the Principal on the HttpServletRequest will be handed off to WebSockets. If you are using Spring Security, the Principal on the HttpServletRequest is overridden automatically.
> 
> More concretely, to ensure a user has authenticated to your WebSocket application, all that is necessary is to ensure that you setup Spring Security to authenticate your HTTP based web application.

You just need to properly setup Spring Security.

To conclude, we have created our own integration of GraphQL Java in Spring at a time when mature and popular solutions did not exist in the Spring / GraphQL community. Our solution comes with both the GraphQLWebSocketHandler and the GraphQLController as the two entry points (WebSocket and HTTP respectively).

We now have popular solutions such as [Netflix DGS](https://netflix.github.io/dgs/) or even the official [Spring GraphQL](https://spring.io/projects/spring-graphql) project for example (which seems to converge with [Netflix DGS which may reuse Spring GraphQL](https://github.com/Netflix/dgs-framework/tree/spring-graphql-integration/graphql-dgs-spring-graphql-bridge)). We may completely remove both entry points and all of our custom GraphQL integration in favor of a standard solution like that in the future. We just did not have the time for that over the past few months. We have no interest in maintaining a custom GraphQL / Spring framework for our project which is why the [CHANGELOG](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/54f3ae3e461c9291db3bfbf093d46a97cd52415f/CHANGELOG.adoc#deprecation-warning-1) of the v0.5.0 had some deprecation warning for our GraphQL integration.

title: NA
body:
Thanks for a thorough explanation, again!

> You just need to properly setup Spring Security.

I believe I did that. All my regular HTTP requests for GraphQL queries and mutations are authenticated correctly, because I am able to pass the authentication token in the HTTP connection headers, which is safe. For WebSockets, there is no way that I know of to provide custom headers.

A way to circumvent that would be to pass the token in as a query parameter to the `/subscriptions` endpoint (e.g. `/subscriptions?token=...`) and then extract it in a security filter. This is not great, though, because many servers/proxies print the whole URLs in their logs, which means auth tokens would be stored in the logs.

As far as I have researched the problem of authenticating GraphQL subscriptions ([here](https://github.com/graphql-java-kickstart/graphql-java-servlet/discussions/134#discussioncomment-225970), [here](https://betterprogramming.pub/understand-graphql-subscriptions-in-java-with-a-tic-tac-toe-game-832ba2729e6d#:~:text=The%20most%20common%20way%20to%20handle%20a%20subscription%20authentication%20is%20using%20the%20payload%20transmitted%20with%20the%20GQL_CONNECTION_INIT%20message.), and [here](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/graphql-subscriptions/authentication/)), the standard way is to provide the token using the [`connectionParams`](https://github.com/apollographql/subscriptions-transport-ws/blob/a8bbabfe375090b44d4a8bd028356ec53d48a23a/src/client.ts#L62) of Apollo WebSocket Link, which includes the token in the `connection_init` message, which is the first to be sent to `/subscriptions`. Then, the server should unwrap that message, and as I see, some Java GraphQL solutions allow registering custom interceptors that get access to those `connectionParams` and are able to set the principal in Spring Security context (like [this one](https://github.com/graphql-java-kickstart/samples/blob/e0918ce7f15599c1040a35d6e9b9c2f1a1584e0a/subscription-with-authentication/src/main/java/subscription/AuthenticationConnectionListener.java)).

I find this last piece to be missing in the proprietary GraphQL server that is implemented in `sirius-components`.

If I understand correctly, you're saying that you're going to focus on removing the proprietary implementation of a GraphQL server that `sirius-components` has, and instead use a ready-made solution like Netflix DGS or Spring GraphQL. If that allows registering custom interceptors that could intercept the token from `connectionParams` - great. Until that is done, however, I don't see a way to authenticate GraphQL subscriptions in `sirius-components` that does not involve providing the token in the query parameters.

As a workaround, I suppose `sirius-components` could allow registering a custom service that would be invoked with the contents of the `connection_init` message, and could set the necessary principal in Spring Security context based on the `connectionParams`. It could be invoked next to https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/ab8097c6c3593f10fdd16f9212762624a3639ccc/backend/sirius-web-spring-graphql/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/spring/graphql/ws/GraphQLWebSocketHandler.java#L255-L256

That requires a brief refactor of that `handleTextMessage` method, though. I understand it may not seem worth it given the fact you're planning on removing this code anyway. From my side, that seems like the only safe solution to authenticate GraphQL subscriptions given the current stack.

Let me know if there is a solution I am not seeing. I understand you cannot share the source code. I would appreciate even a brief description of the idea.

title: NA
body:
I thought about our integration with Spring Security yesterday and I believe that we could make Sirius Components even more flexible by removing the dependency to Spring Security from the whole project. We still have remnants of Spring Security related code here or there but they are not relevant anymore and it forces us to keep that weird hack on the Sirius Web side. It would make it even easier to integrate Sirius Components since it would not come with a pre-established opinion on the topic.

> Let me know if there is a solution I am not seeing. I understand you cannot share the source code. I would appreciate even a brief description of the idea.

Honestly everything is in the Spring Security documentation link that I have provided. If the security of the HTTP layer is properly done and if it requires some authentication, then this authentication is provided for the WebSocket layer by the HTTP handshake request of the WebSocket connection. There's nothing required on the Apollo side as far as I remember, there's nothing specific to GraphQL or subscriptions, that's really a 100% Spring Security question and I'll find answers for that on the Spring Security documentation or Stack Overflow.

title: NA
body:
> If the security of the HTTP layer is properly done and if it requires some authentication, then this authentication is provided for the WebSocket layer by the HTTP handshake request of the WebSocket connection. There's nothing required on the Apollo side as far as I remember, there's nothing specific to GraphQL or subscriptions, that's really a 100% Spring Security question and I'll find answers for that on the Spring Security documentation or Stack Overflow.

Sadly, I did not find any concrete answer to this that would not involve intercepting the `connection_init` message, which I don't think is possible with the existing GraphQL implementation in Sirius Components. Believe me, I did spend a few hours on this topic already with no luck so far. Do you know what the answer is? If so, could you share some concrete tips?

So far in my previous comments, I believe I was pinpointing exact ways I found on how to achieve authentication for WebSocket connections and which parts of Sirius Components are preventing me from doing that, and I am being redirected to StackOverflow, which does not help

title: Add support for `service:` expressions
body:
Sirius Desktop VSMs can make use of the `var:/feature:/service:` core interpreters in addition to the more powerful `aql:`.
We already support `var:` and `feature:` in `org.eclipse.sirius.web.interpreter.ExpressionConverter` by rewriting them into an equivalent AQL expression.
It seems we could also support `service:` with relatively simple rewrite rules:
* `service:myService` or `service:myService()` => `aql:self.myService()
* `service:someVar.myService()` => `aql:someVar.myService()`
* `service:someVar.myService(var1, var2)` => `aql:someVar.myService(var1, var2)` (arguments can only be plain variable names in `service:` expressions)

title: Remove deprecated references to username
body:
Hey!

When trying to enable authentication in Sirius Web I noticed the SQL queries used by the `IProjectRepository` do not restrict access to projects based on the `username`

https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/4b91a66492ea1302c222a24c069389a4a207aede/backend/sirius-web-persistence/src/main/resources/db/sirius-web-named-queries.properties#L1-L4

even though it is provided as a parameter

https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/4b91a66492ea1302c222a24c069389a4a207aede/backend/sirius-web-persistence/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/persistence/repositories/IProjectRepository.java#L38-L52

I understand Sirius Web is using a single hardcoded `system` user at the moment, so the username does not matter. On the other hand, there seems to be no harm in verifying the username in the queries, because the `system` account is still created, so all queries should return the same results regardless of whether they check the username or not.

Having the username be verified in those SQL queries by default would mean there are fewer changes needed to enable authentication for anyone wanting to develop their own modeler based on Sirius Web.

Just FYI, I added it myself in my work in https://github.com/Gelio/CAL-web/pull/111/commits/fad18f5e6bc5a3b463a29c0ea8498ca83f573eb6 (note that I did not modify all the queries, partly due to https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/issues/846#issuecomment-983440899), but IMO it's worth adding to the upstream repository.

title: NA
body:
Hi,

The code in question has been contributed to Sirius Web quite recently (in August) when we moved all those projects from Sirius Components to Sirius Web:

- sirius-web-persistence
- sirius-web-services-api
- sirius-web-services
- sirius-web-graphql-schema
- sirius-web-graphql
- sirius-web-spring

While those projects were in Sirius Components, their goal was to provide everything to support applications built on top of Sirius Components. We quickly realized that Sirius Components was being used in applications with very different lifecycles and architectures. As a result, we made some massive changes to Sirius Components to reduce its scope to focus it around representation management. This is why we have removed from Sirius Components any persistence related code or most of our GraphQL specific code too. As a result, you can now more easily reuse Sirius Components with the database you want or the GraphQL framework of your choice.

When we have started all those projects (when it was closed source), there weren't a ton of good solutions to integrate GraphQL Java with Spring for example, so we came up with our own solution which we are in the process of removing piece by piece. We have removed the data fetchers and type providers from Sirius Components, pretty much everything in `sirius-web-graphql-utils` will be removed soon. In order to let consumers used solutions such as Netflix DGS if they want to.

We have also removed a lot of the complexity from those projects in order to stop trying to support all those different use cases since there are so many of them. Sirius Web is a simple web application showing Sirius Components in action. The goal of Sirius Web is not to be an enterprise ready application to be deployed on the cloud for anyone to use. As such, we do not try to provide authentication or authorization support. We tried in the past in Sirius Components and we had so many different authentication strategies used by some of our users that we just stopped trying to support everything and instead gave them more freedom to just do what they want. Another issue related to that was our strategy to persist account information. Some of our users wanted to have a different database schema of even a remote service to retrieve said account informations etc. You can still find some remnants of this code here and there in Sirius Web such as this username argument in the `IProjectRepository` but those are parts of the code that should have been removed.

Sirius Web is not a web application on top of which every application trying to integrate Sirius Components should be built (We tried that when the code was in Sirius Components).

Sirius Web is meant to be a simple web application integrating Sirius Components to show:

- what Sirius Components can do since most of the core behavior is in Sirius Components
- how to build your own web application on top of Sirius Components

It is meant to be used as is to manipulate Sirius Components as an end user or It is meant to be forked, heavily modified as you which, change the database schema, add anything you like, plug the authentication / authorization strategy that you need etc if you want to build a more advanced version of Sirius Web. We will not try to restrict access by username, we will instead remove even more of those remnants of code which can still be found here and there but for your use case, you can do as you please, change anything you want in your fork.

title: The View DSL should expose all the features supported by the  representations core
body:
Everything that is available programmatically by creating a custom `org.eclipse.sirius.web.diagrams.description.DiagramDescription` should be available to studio makers directly in the web using the View DSL.

Note that in the Java API all actions are defined in plain Java. In the view DSL the tools' effect is specified using model operations which correspond more or less to the Sirius Desktop model operations. Improving this part of the DSL is not in the scope of this specific ticket and will be treated separately.

Also note that this is a moving target: as the diagram core evolves a gains new features, the View DSL will need to be improved in parallel. For now, the scope is simply to match the current scope.

title: Add automated tests for the dynamic studios feature
body:
We've had at least one time where some change in the core made the dynamic studio feature completely broken, and we did not notice it immediatly as there are no automated tests and nobody was using it manually at the time.
Of course ideally we would have good test coverage of the whole feature, but the very minimum would be a non-regression test on some basic use case.

title: Configure EMF to be more lenient when loading odesign models
body:
When it loads `odesign` models, Sirius Desktop configure EMF (XMLResource and XMIResource) to try its best but not to throw an error if it finds XML elements which do not correspond to anything in the metamodel (`XMLResource.OPTION_RECORD_UNKNOWN_FEATURE`, and maybe other options). This is used to support migration participants by post-processing the recorded information.

Sirius Components does not setup these options. The result is that some `odesign` files which, while technically invalid, work perfectly fine in Sirius Desktop, cause an exception when loaded in Sirius Components, and are thus unusable. For example:

> Caused by: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.FeatureNotFoundException: Feature 'initialOperation' not found. (example.odesign, 1239, 33)

While we do not plan to support the migration mechanism in Sirius Components, we could probably be a little more flexible here by setting the proper EMF options. Of course we may want to log a message in the cases where the loaded odesign was technically invalid.

title: NA
body: Obsolete, direct support for odesign files is on its way out.

title: AQL is not interpreted correctly in style customizations for image `workspacePath`
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** :
- other: 0.5.3
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : 
- Ubuntu 20.04 LTS

### Screenshots

Some of my style customizations in the odesign file use AQL. An example style customization:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/144719096-24eef6b4-472f-4c76-b76c-48ac6098c54c.png)

`getDataPinIconPath` is defined in my metamodel's `Services`.

It works well in Sirius Desktop:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/144719112-3b3c1a25-006e-46b7-9113-5b22c0daa577.png)

But there are no images shown in Sirius Web:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/144719070-1bc0b763-12a1-4404-b0e1-cc1bd7805e74.png)

The image path that Sirius Web wants to load is:

```
http://localhost:3000/api/images/eu.balticlsc.model.CAL.edit/icons/computed-data-pin/'%20+%20self.declared.getDataPinIconPath()
```

whereas it should be:

```
http://localhost:3000/api/images/eu.balticlsc.model.CAL.edit/icons/computed-data-pin/single-data-single-token.png
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add a metamodel style customization using AQL for the `workspacePath` of an image of a node

### Expected behavior

The image is loaded correctly using the same logic as in Sirius Desktop.

### Actual behavior

The image is not loaded due to a malformed URL.

title: NA

title: It should be possible to create a non-trivial modeling studio without relying on Sirius Desktop at all
body:
We now have a first working version of the web-based studio definition (domain and views), but they are rather limited. For more complex cases, studio makers have to rely either on our Java APIs and/or to our Sirius Desktop compatibility layer, creating their Ecore-based metamodel and odesign configuration files from e.g. Obeo Designer and then importing them into Sirius Web.

It should be possible to create non-trivial modeling studios without using Sirius Desktop at all.
The studio maker should be able to define as much as possible of his/her studio without leaving his/her browser. For the more complex cases where that is not possible (e.g. to call complex operations which only make sense to define in Java), there should be a (documented) way to do this without using the Eclipse EMF tooling or Sirius Desktop / Obeo Designer (it's OK to use the Eclipse-based STS for example, but it should work with other tools).

This issue will be refined in more specific tickets as needed, for example #851, to add the features and fix the bugs which prevent the goal to be achieved.

Examples of studios that it should be possible to define: 
* component diagrams similar (but simpler of course) to what it available in Capella
* entity diagrams similar to the ones in [IS Designer](https://github.com/ObeoNetwork/InformationSystem)
* state machine diagrams

![component-diagram](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/144836029-5a4c14a7-43d2-4b94-83a0-c7e8a52af46a.jpeg)

![entity-diagram-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/144836053-50b98932-36e6-45ba-b5b6-69ffe9399502.png)

![state-machine-example-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/144836073-eac91287-e912-4597-896b-4f574cef702b.jpg)

title: Incremental layout service shouldn't append any changes to the diagram after moving
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [ ] **I have specified the version** :
- latest

Currently, When performing any manual layout, the backend service will calculate every element to the wanted status like size and position. and send it to the user. which makes many unexpected issues(see below cases). and lead to a bad experience.

### Screenshots


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19710731/145186023-a15b4aa5-4f25-4af1-9a4e-59577a20472c.mov



## Case1
### Steps to reproduce
Moving a node with a labeled edge 
### Expected behavior
The edge label change to the right position on the fly.
### Actual behavior
The edge label had an inconsistent position between moving and finished.


## Case2
### Steps to reproduce
Moving a node frequently.
### Expected behavior
The node moves to the mouse release position without further changes.
### Actual behavior
After finishing the consecutive move actions, the node will continue to move. Which is demanded by the incremental layout service.

## What's the incremental layout logic I expected:

The incremental layout should only record which diagram element has changed then the backend saved the changes. No calculation should be performed. As though the user is patching changes and the backend service is recording.

title: NA
body:
While this issue highlights some problems with the incremental layout of the backend which can produce results which are not aligned with the frontend, I want to clarify some details on why things are this way.

In Sirius Desktop, we had lot of difficulties coming from the fact that the diagram engine did not control every parts of the diagram rendering especially the size / position of the nodes. In Sirius Components, the backend is in charge of those properties and the size / position of the diagram in the `DiagramEventProcessor` is the sole source of truth regarding the full layout of a diagram while it is being edited. This has been done on purpose based on our experience in Sirius Desktop and I don't see us change from that approach to something with a frontend computed layout in the foreseeable future because it makes some use cases almost impossible to handle. We even started Sirius Web (before it was open sourced) with some frontend computed layout and moved it all to the backend.

title: NA
body: Do we have any plan to solve those issues or is it has a low priority currently?  Moreover, I think we can use the auto-layout diagram to be the full backend-charged layout to the user.  In manual layout, if the backend layout service does some computation after moving, those issues could be hard to handle.

title: NA
body: We are planning to work on several usability issues including some layouting issues over the next few weeks but I don't think we will change this core part.

title: Add support for defining unsynchronized nodes and edges
body:
The View DSL should support the definition of unsychronized elements.

Adding support for the SynchronizationPolicy itself is trivial, but it only makes sense if it is possible to use operations like "Create View" and "Delete View" in tool definitions.

title: It is possible to create instances of the `NamedElement` type in `domain.ecore` but they can not be displayed
body:
### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new project.
2. Create a _Domain_ model inside.
3. On the context menu of the _Domain_ model itself (not the automatically create element inside), select _New Object_
4. Choose `http://www.eclipse.org/sirius-web/domain` as domain and uncheck the "Show only suggested root types" checkbox
5. The object type selected is "Named Element". This is the first bug 🐛: `NamedElement` should be abstract and not proposed here
6. Click on "Create". Nothing is visible in the explorer, with no error feedback. There is a stacktrace in the backend 🐛:

```
java.util.MissingResourceException: The image resource 'full/obj16/NamedElement' could not be located
	at org.eclipse.emf.common.util.DelegatingResourceLocator.delegatedGetImage(DelegatingResourceLocator.java:388) ~[org.eclipse.emf.common-2.21.0.jar:na]
	at org.eclipse.emf.common.util.DelegatingResourceLocator.getImage(DelegatingResourceLocator.java:303) ~[org.eclipse.emf.common-2.21.0.jar:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.domain.provider.NamedElementItemProvider.getImage(NamedElementItemProvider.java:85) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.emf.services.ObjectService.getImagePath(ObjectService.java:150) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.services.explorer.ExplorerDescriptionProvider.getImageURL(ExplorerDescriptionProvider.java:180) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.trees.renderer.TreeRenderer.renderTreeItem(TreeRenderer.java:71) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.trees.renderer.TreeRenderer.renderTreeItem(TreeRenderer.java:79) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.trees.renderer.TreeRenderer.render(TreeRenderer.java:51) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.spring.collaborative.trees.TreeService.create(TreeService.java:40) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.spring.collaborative.trees.TreeEventProcessor.refreshTree(TreeEventProcessor.java:178) ~[classes/:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.spring.collaborative.trees.TreeEventProcessor.refresh(TreeEventProcessor.java:130) ~[classes/:na]
```

title: NA
body:
There are two different issues:

1. `NamedElement` should be abstract (it was meant to be).
2. The backend should be more robust to this kind of exception, which can happen in case of packaging issues (or plain missing icons).

title: The label of the canonical CreateEdgeTool could be improved
The default EdgeTool created cannot work
body:
When you create a new `EdgeDescription`, a canonical `EdgeCreateTool` is generated on the fly. If you want to customize it, then you can create an `EdgeTool` and by default it starts with a ChangeContext operation with the value `aql:self` but there is not `self` variable in the `InvokeEdgeToolOnDiagramEventHandler.executeTool(...)` so it will fail. It should be `aql: semanticEdgeSource`instead.

Slightly off topic, we should also probably document somewhere the variable accessible because even I had to look at the source code to find out what was available (that's an issue way outside of the scope of the metamodeling part)

title: Compatibility layer: handle DotDescription style for Bordered Nodes
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

Handle Dot style for Bordered Nodes in the compatibility layer.
A Dot is simply a RectangularNodeStyle with a radius = 100. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

A new CircleNodeStyle could be implemented instead of using RectangularNodeStyle with a radius = 100

title: NA
body: I don't understand how we can says that this implements the `DotDescription` from Sirius Desktop, which are represented using a circle. The changelog should a least mention what "handled" means here.

title: NA
body: A SVG rectangle with a 100 radius is a circle. No change require on the frontend this way.

title: NA
body:
But the border radius is an absolute dimension, not a percentage. It will only render as a Sirius Desktop "Dot" at small sizes:

![2021-12-30_10-22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/147738688-572b8949-e243-4f18-bba4-14d742cde399.png)
 
Yes, in SVG the `rx` attribute [*can* be a percentage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/rx#rect), but in our case `RectangularNodeStyle.getBorderRadius()` is an `int` which we always convert as a plain length.

I guess we could embrace the fact that we will render as SVGs, make `RectangularNodeStyle.getBorderRadius()` a string and return `"100%"` in this case. Which would offer more flexibility to programatically defined modelers to chose between absolute lengths and percentage. Or add a "hack" to interpret negative values as percentage in `RectangleView.tsx` and return `-100` here.

title: NA
body: You're right, I believed that we were interpreting it as a percentage on the frontend. We could indeed make `RectangularNodeStyle.getBorderRadius()` a string. We could even create different border radius configurations for each corner. Using that philosophy, I'm not sure why we would not remove both `RectangularNodeStyle.getBorderSize()` and `RectangularNodeStyle.getBorderRadius()` in favor of a string based `RectangularNodeStyle.getBorder()` since it would allow us to create way more complex borders.

title: NA
body: :+1: to "embrace SVG and CSS" (and not try to hide/abstract their more powerful features)

title: The presence of a border node can prevent the resize of a node
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** : v2021.12.07
* [x] **I have specified my environment** :  All

### Screenshots

![2022-01-05_17-23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/148252236-aee7997b-09b0-4326-aa46-6f49c94de7a9.png)


### Steps to reproduce

In the screenshot above, trying to reduce the size of the "New Component" node from the right border (in the direction of the red arrow) does not work. It is blocked by the presence of the border node, which is considered "inside" and enforces a minimum size (which is the correct/expected behavior for actual children nodes).

Note that of course the same behavior occurs for all the sides as soon as they have at least one border node on them.
In  the extreme case, a node which has border nodes on all sides can not be made smaller from any direction (expect by moving some border nodes elsewhere, doing the resize and then resetting them).

### Expected behavior

The presence of border nodes should not block the resizing.

title: Layout issues when using large border widths
body:
![2022-01-07_14-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/148554374-a930503b-4825-4e15-991f-269b19bb6c45.png)

This is a little extreme to make the problems obvious, but when using a large border width on a node:

1. the resize handlers appear "inside" the element, when they are supposed to be attached to the selection outline.
2. the starting and ending points of the edges also appear in the inside
3. depending on the font size and border size, the label can overlap with the border

The issues are present even when using pretty normal border widths, but of course are less obivous there.

body:

- latest

- my computer: Windows

### Screenshots

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7371042/148558673-7037a108-0aa5-47cb-8887-fc4b32416eb5.mp4

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create two edges between two same elements
2. Remove the first edge created

### Expected behavior

The remaining edge keeps its position

### Actual behavior

The remaining edge take the position of the removed edge

title: NA
body:
Since many edges can be displayed between two same elements, a hidden issue is now visible.
This behavior is due to the way edge ids are defined. Among other parameters, we use the number of edges present in the diagram to calculate the id of an edge. Which explains the actual behavior.

To fix this issue we should rely on edge anchors instead of a counter to build edge ids.

title: Introduce the RepresentationMetadata concept

title: Move from the old Eclipse CheckStyle 8.12 to the latest 9.1
body:
Sirius Components uses the same [CheckStyle configuration](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/master/backend/sirius-web-resources/checkstyle/CheckstyleConfiguration.xml) as Sirius Desktop, which has been stuck on CheckStyle 8.12 for years (which has become difficult to find/install since BinTray is gone, see https://github.com/pcdavid/eclipse-cs-8.12).

It turns out the [changes](https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/sirius/org.eclipse.sirius/+/189382) needed to make the configuration compatible with the most recent versions are pretty trivial (thanks @GlennPlou for this!):

```
--- a/releng/org.eclipse.sirius.settings/CheckstyleConfiguration.xml
+++ b/releng/org.eclipse.sirius.settings/CheckstyleConfiguration.xml
@@ -13,11 +13,10 @@
   <module name="TreeWalker">
     <module name="SuppressionCommentFilter"/>
     <module name="SuppressWarningsHolder"/>
-    <module name="JavadocMethod">
+    <module name="MissingJavadocMethodCheck">
       <property name="severity" value="error"/>
       <property name="scope" value="protected"/>
       <property name="allowMissingPropertyJavadoc" value="true"/>
-      <property name="suppressLoadErrors" value="true"/>
     </module>
     <module name="JavadocStyle">
       <property name="severity" value="error"/>
```

We should probably apply this change on the Sirius Components config and move to the latest Eclipse CS ([version 9.1.0](https://github.com/checkstyle/eclipse-cs/releases/tag/9.1.0) has just been released and [matches the latest CheckStyle version](https://checkstyle.org/eclipse-cs/#!/releasenotes)) from the official repo at https://checkstyle.org/eclipse-cs-update-site/

The actual change is rather trivial (though CS 9.1 might detect new errors/warnings to fix), the only thing is to make sure all contributors are aware of it.

title: Add the ability to dispose the IEditingContext

title: Add an explicit text color for labels, distinct from the corresponding node/edge's base color
body:
Nodes have a distinct `labelColor`, but for edges the label's text color uses the edge's main color.
For edges, it should at least be possible to configure the labels' color differently from the edge's color.
Ideally each of the 3 possible labels on an edge should have distinct styles, but that is not a hard requirement for now.

title: IndexOutOfBounds while computing the position of the label of an edge
body: In `EdgeLabelPositionProvider`, we are checking if there are at least 2 routing points but we are using `routingPoints.get(2)` just after. We should either use `routingPoints.get(0)` and `routingPoints.get(1)` instead of `routingPoints.get(1)` and `routingPoints.get(2)` or check that there are at least three routing points.

title: The optional "begin" and "end" labels are layouted in the wrong order by the auto-layout
body:
When setting a "begin label" and "end label" on an edge, one expects the "begin" (resp. "end") one to appear on the source side of the edge (resp. target side). This is how it works in Sirius Desktop for example.
This is not what `org.eclipse.sirius.web.diagrams.layout.ELKDiagramConverter.convertEdge()`. It maps "begin" (resp. "eng") to ELK's `EdgeLabelPlacement.HEAD` (resp. `EdgeLabelPlacement.TAIL)`. This is reverted: what ELK calls the head of the edge is its target/end side, and what it calls tail is the source/begin side.

![2022-01-12_14-45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10608/149151871-adb86e02-7e1d-490e-806a-45232b9c3ee1.png)

title: The contextual palette can be too long
Border nodes appear inside of their container
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** :
- 2021.12.7
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : 
- Ubuntu 20.04 LTS

### Screenshots

Note that the border nodes are inside of the container
![border-node-sirius-web](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/149277635-b0cb744f-75c8-4b9e-8a44-948b6a0670fc.png)


Whereas in Sirius Desktop they are correctly rendered right outside the border of the container

![border-node-sirius-desktop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/149277634-753664cd-a1a1-46b6-b338-17a8a16a011a.png)

Interestingly, the border nodes are positioned correctly after I force rearrangement of elements on the diagram, but they go back into the container after I try to move them

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/889383/149199243-1201cf86-282c-4970-927c-edc36717c904.mp4

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open a model that has border nodes

### Expected behavior

Border nodes appear on the edge of their container, just like in Sirius Desktop



### Actual behavior

Border nodes appear inside of their container, not making them _border_ nodes anymore.

I thought https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/issues/359 was supposed to fix it, but it seems I was wrong. The problem is also visible in the screenshots in that issue, though, so it seems like a regression.

title: NA
body: Small comment for myself and the rest of the team: I'm pretty sure that on the frontend side at least, the solution should involve a better support for `SPort` which should have a different move strategy.

title: NA
body:
I'm not so sure. Sprotty's SPorts are not SNodes. It's a different type of element, which in particular does not have children. It seems designed more as "anchor points" for incoming/outgoing edges, but in Sirius border nodes have all the capabilities of other nodes (they can have their own children, and even their own border nodes). The only thing that makes them special is that their location is constrained to the (rectangular) bounding box of their parent.

Sprotty's type hierarchy seems to match [ELK's metamodel](https://www.eclipse.org/elk/documentation/tooldevelopers/graphdatastructure.html#graph-data-structure):
* `SConnectableElement` <-> `ElkConnectableShape`
* `SNode extends SConnectableElement` <-> `ElkNode extends ElkConnectableShape`
* `SPort extends SConnectableElement` <-> `ElkPort extends ElkConnectableShape`

ELK has the same limitation.

So it seems there are two options:
1. Use the `SPort` mechanism anyway, and accept that Sirius Components will only support a subset of what Sirius border nodes can do (granted, it's the most common use case, but our APIs are more generic than that: ` {oes}.components.diagrams.Node.getBorderNodes()` is a generic `List<Node>`, which can themselves have children & border nodes). It might not be that simple as `SNode` does not extend `SPort` (so, code duplication or dynamic type checks to handle both cases with the same code).
2. Continue to use `SNode` to represent border nodes, but make the code (frontend, ELK, incremental layout) aware that their position is constrained compared to plain child nodes (e.g. extending [SiriusDragAndDropMouseListener#getValidPosition()](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-components/blob/d9f07a2202c34735e76eaffa3d4731d2a10d89fe/frontend/src/diagram/sprotty/siriusDragAndDropMouseListener.ts#L107) for the front-end/interactive move part).

title: NA
body:
Yes that's a core part of the issue. I wonder if it's worth trying to support border nodes as nodes. We could simply convert border nodes to `ElkPort` on the backend and `SPort` on the frontend and while the diagram API could theoretically support border nodes with border nodes or child nodes, in practice it would not be supported for now.

Have you encountered, over the years, that many Sirius RCP diagrams with border nodes containing child nodes or border nodes?

title: NA
body:
> Have you encountered, over the years, that many Sirius RCP diagrams with border nodes containing child nodes or border nodes?

Technically the Sirius Desktop support for sequence diagrams is almost entirely based on that capacity (lifelines are border nodes of the participant nodes, and all executions on a lifeline are border nodes of the lifeline or of their parent execution). But that is a very special case.

I don't have other concrete examples, so I guess we can decide to only support the common case.

There's still the issue that SPorts are not SNode, so going this route, while being more in line with how Sprotty and ELK work, may require some duplication or refactorings to get the same behaviors we have on nodes available on ports (styling, tool application, direct edit, etc.). We'll see when I start concretely (soon).

title: NA
body: On the backend, we already convert border nodes to `ElkPort` in `ELKDiagramConverter#convertBorderNode` so I think that this part is already ok (which is why the arrange all correctly put the border nodes on the border of their container). I think that the main issue is that `convertDiagram` on the frontend does not convert our border nodes to our `Port` type but instead to our `Node` type. You should start looking there to see what are the consequences of such change.

title: NA
body:
> I think that the main issue is that `convertDiagram` on the frontend does not convert our border nodes to our `Port` type but instead to our `Node` type.

Already started on that, but currently stuck with `GraphFactory` creating plain Nodes for my BorderNodes/Ports. I'm not very familiar with the part of Sprotty, but I'm investigating. I'll keep updating here with what I find.

Note that one limitation of `SPort` is that they can not have children, which (from what I understand) means no labels. Not supporting the complex "border nodes on border nodes with nodes inside them" case is OK, but not supporting labels not so much. Sure it's probably possible to add it, but not sure how much work that would involve.

title: NA
body:
Actually, `SPort extends SConnectableElement extends SShapeElement  extends SChildElement extends SParentElement`... which has a `children` property, but defined as readonly:

```ts
readonly children: ReadonlyArray<SChildElement> = [];
```

`SNode` redefines a `children` property as mutable array: `children: SChildElement[];`

It seems we're supposed to use `SParentElement.add/remove` to add/remove children, the methods ensuring the index is kept up to date.

title: Investigate a potential performance issue with the initial FitToScreenAction
body: There are multiple events which can trigger an `InitializeCanvasBoundsAction` and as such which can trigger a `FitToScreenAction` on our side such as resizing the window apparently. As a result, the whole operation can be very slow with potentially multiple `FitToScreenAction` performed.

title: Nodes are not always properly resized when a child node is created

- resize it manually a little

The node will not be resized to be able to properly contain its newly created child node. Somewhere in the incremental layout, we should invalidate the previous size if the node is too small to contain the new child.

title: NA

After reproducing this issue, the problem is quite simple, the onboard area is not synchronized and as such it can display outdated data. Everything is fine on the backend. It just appears that you could not delete a representation before without opening it which hides the onboard area. As a result deleting a representation with this workflow would refresh the onboard area.

You can achieve the same result if you open the onboard area with an existing representation and someone else deletes the representation on their side. It would still be visible on the onboard area and we would have the same error.

title: ViewValidator only considers dynamic domains when validating domain types
body:
When creating a new diagram definition as a dynamic View, the _Domain Type_ of a _Diagram Description_ (or Node/Edge) is validated by `ViewValidator.hasProperDomainType()`, which only looks for a matching type inside the EPackages defined from a domain.
There is no particular reason for this restriction. The view part of dynamic studios should work on instances of any EPackage, whether it is create "on the fly" from a domain or contributed statically as a more classical Ecore-generated metamodel.
