title: Add support for For construct in the operations DSL
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

The pull request: https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/pull/3448

### Expected behavior

`For` operation is available in Sirius Desktop, so it will be useful in Sirius Web.

For instance, we use domain based edges (relationships described using a EClass in a metamodel). A deletion tool for objects should remove not only objects, but also should find all domain based edges related to a deleted object and remove them as well. We use an expression of the following form `aql:self.eContainer(ns::Model).relationships->select(rel | rel.source = self or rel.target = self)` to iterate over all related relationships and remove them.

### Cuttings backs

No

### Potential side effects

Operations DSL can become too complicated?

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Implement a Java-service, but it's too complicated for non-developers who creates a dynamic metamodel and representation specification.

### Questions

I've got some questions, could you please help?

1. What is a right way to generate code for changed Ecore-files? Just open a genmodel-file and use "Generate All" command? But it generates some extra files (build.properties, plugin.xml), also tests are failed for generated files. Maybe you use some Maven command to regenerate all?
2. How to generate builders in `sirius-components-view-builder` package?
3. Should For-operation automatically change context to current iterator value? Or ChangeContext operation should be explicit? Sirius desktop changes context automatically for For-operations and CreateInstance-operations. But Sirius Web doesn't do it for CreateInstance. Should it? I think that auto changing of a context is handy, but it's safer not to implement it now, so people will not rely on it and their specifications will not be broken in future if you decide to change that behaviour
4. I've got a build error "more tests are required" for projects `sirius-components-view` and `sirius-components-view-edit`. I don't what kind of tests I can add. Maybe there are some examples?

title: Fix unnecessary ConnectionTargetHandle rerender
body:
When opening a diagram, the hook `useRefreshTargetHandles` that is used by each nodes that have for children a `ConnectionTargetHandle` is executed. This is sending one `nodeDimensionChange` event for each nodes in the diagram thus calling `setNodes` for each nodes. This is causing a big delay when opening a diagram.

Also, when initiating a new connection, `useRefreshTargetHandles` is called for each nodes candidates and result in the same issue as above if the diagram contains lots of nodes candidate.

We will now only call `useRefreshTargetHandles` if a node is `hovered` and is a candidate for a new connection.

title: Update documents on domain or view change
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

The pull request: https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/pull/3463

### Expected behavior

One changes a domain or view. And then models and diagrams (based on the domain or view) are automatically updated without application restart. For example, I change a node style in a view, and all nodes are automatically updated on a diagram.

It's very controversial feature, but I propose it anyway. Maybe you will find it useful.

### Cuttings backs

At now only a current editing context is updated. Ideally all editing contexts dependent on changed domains or views should be updated. However maybe it's better to update a current editing context only, so it can be used for testing. It's very handy to change a view and see an updated diagram immediately.

An editing context is updated on any change of a domain or view, even on focus change. We should update the editing context only if necessary.

### Potential side effects

Performance issues, because an editing context is updated on any change of a domain or view. Maybe you can help to fix it?

Model or diagram corruption, for instance, on class renaming. But they can be corrupted anyway. This pull requests just increases a frequency of model and diagram update.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Add an explicit "Reload" command to models and diagrams. However it would not be so handy.

### Notes on the code

1. `EditingContextSearchService::findById()` always creates a new editing context. It's impossible to get an existing editing context used by event processors. I changed this behaviour. Added a cache of editing contexts and now  `EditingContextSearchService` creates a new one only if necessary.

2. I had to add `IEMFEditingContext::isDisposed()` method, so `EditingContextSearchService` can determine that an editing context was disposed and it should be removed from the cache.

3. Changed type of `EditingContext::views` from `List<View>` to `Map<String, View>`. It allows to update a changed view only. Not to reload all views.

In general this feature is crucial for us. But the implementation is very hacky. Maybe you could suggest some improvements? Or it should be implemented in a completely different way?

title: Improve i18n support for domain and view forms
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

The pull request: https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/pull/3465

### Expected behavior

We need to localize domain and view forms. But there are two problems:

1. Some strings are hard-coded on backend
2. Identifiers of child creation descriptions are locale-dependent. When I add localization files tests become broken

I suggest to fix it and simplify localization

### Cuttings backs

No.

### Potential side effects

No.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Add a localization on the application level, but it's a way more complicated and impossible for some strings, because they are hard-coded.

### What's changed

1. Added `EEnumLiteralLabelProvider` that gets a localized label for EEnumLiteral

3. Added i18n support for `DomainPropertiesConfigurer`, `MultipleDomainPropertiesConfigurer`, `FixedColorPropertiesConfigurer`, `PropertiesWidgetCreationService`, `NodeStylePropertiesConfigurer`, `EdgeStylePropertiesConfigurer` and some other classes

4. Changed `DefaultEditService::getChildCreationDescriptions()` and `DefaultEditService::createChild()`. They used `helper.getCreateChildText()` to get a localized child description identifiers. So these identifiers changed after I added localization and tests was broken. Now I replaced identifiers by ones of the form: `containmentFeatureName-ChildClassName`. They guaranteed to be locale-independent and unique

5. Added to `DefaultLabelService::getLabel()` usage of `IItemLabelProvider`

6. Removed `packages/view/backend/sirius-components-view-emf/src/main/resources/messages/sirius-web-emf.properties`. It overrided `packages/emf/backend/sirius-components-emf/src/main/resources/messages/sirius-web-emf.properties` during tests in GitHub and leaded to strange test fails

7. Added ru localization for several packages

title: The full-screen state is shared among all representations in a portal
body:
### Setup

1. Create a project with many representations and a portal representation
2. In the portal representation, add all others representations
3. Toggle the portal full-screen mode

The actual behavior make all full-screen buttons state from displayed representations the same as the state of the portal full-screen button.
That means, starting from the _Setup_ state we toggle the full-screen mode of a contained representation, that leave the full-screen mode.

This issue has been created to start the discussion about that matter because the actual behavior may not be the one we want.
We may want something like :

1. Starting from the _Setup_ state
2. Toggle the full-screen mode displays the representation in full-screen mode
3. Toggle the full-screen mode again of that representation (to leave the full-screen mode of that representation) may result in:
    - either, we get back to the full-screen mode of the portal (full-screen mode are "stacked")
    - or, we leave the full-screen mode completely

title: When moving a task in Gantt, have the ability to define how to round start and end dates
body:
* [X] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

In Gantt, when moving the task or changing the start or end date with the handler, the date should be rounded with a value defined in the View model

It introduces GanttDescription.roundDate expression that defines this round number

The round date is made of two parts :

- a numerical part corresponding to amount of time
- a letter among (D, H and M) that corresponds to respectively day, hour and minute

The round is done with lower value (Math.floor)

**Example**: 
* To round the date to half a day : 12H -> 20241203T10:37 is rounded to  20241203T00:00
* To round the date to a day : 1D -> 20241203T23:37 is rounded to  20241203T00:00
* To round the date to 2 hours: 1D -> 20241203T23:37 is rounded to  20241203T22:00


### Cuttings backs

NA

### Potential side effects

NA

title: Register transient representation descriptions in the editing contexts
body:
In the new architecture, [`RepresentationMetadataDescriptionDataFetcher`](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/master/packages/sirius-web/backend/sirius-web-application/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/application/representation/controllers/RepresentationMetadataDescriptionDataFetcher.java) does not include the special treatment [the old version had](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/master/packages/sirius-web/backend/sirius-web-graphql/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/graphql/datafetchers/representation/RepresentationMetadataDescriptionDataFetcher.java) for find the details view and explorer view's descriptions.

This is normal, but it means a query like `query getReferenceValueOptions()` does not find the details view representation description and (incorrectly) returns null.

The proper solution is for these representation descriptions to be registered inside the editing context when loaded (via an `IEditingContextProcessor#preProcess`) so that they can be found like any other. This also means that `PropertiesEventProcessorFactory`, `RelatedElementsEventProcessorFactory` and `RepresentationsEventProcessorFactory` could get the proper representation description directly from the editing context instead of requesting a new copy of the representation description from their special-purpose providers (e.g. `this.propertiesDefaultDescriptionProvider.getFormDescription()`).

title: Remove duplicate dependencies in our pom.xml
body: While analyzing our dependency tree with Papaya, it is very clear that some of our Maven modules have unnecessary duplicated dependencies (visible in red in the screenshot above). The two biggest offenders are `sirius-components-annotations-spring` which is rightfully used by `sirius-components-graphql-api` but useless used as a duplicate by all the other `...-graphql` modules and `sirius-components-annotations` which should only be used by `sirius-components-representations` since pretty much everybody will end up depending on it. I should try to setup the dependency tree in the Papaya sample from the result of `mvn dependency:tree` to ensure that I'm not missing anything later.

Add support for the other positions : TOP_LEFT, TOP_RIGHT, BOTTOM_CENTER, BOTTOM_LEFT, BOTTOM_RIGHT, MIDDLE_CENTER, MIDDLE_LEFT, MIDDLE_RIGHT

### Expected behavior

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/128395825/ec8c714e-877c-466a-a128-6a6c03221d68)

title: Avoid costly recomputations in MigrationService
body:
The various methods in `MigrationService` are invoked *a lot* when loading a model. For example when loading the new "Sirius Web" Papaya project (about 120k semantic elements):

![Capture d’écran du 2024-06-04 10-03-33](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/c2ec8b70-605d-421c-bd1d-d784bc1f2d04)

This accounts for a non-trivial amount of time (loading the same model):

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/f04d2d38-0865-46a1-a78e-2fc216971f76)

Upon analysis, almost all methods recompute the sorted list of applicable migration participants onn every invocation:

```java
        var migrationParticipantsCandidates = this.migrationParticipants.stream()
                .filter(this::isCandidateVersion)
                .sorted(Comparator.comparing(IMigrationParticipant::getVersion))
                .toList();
```

This only depends on `migrationParticipants` (fixed on creation) and `documentMigrationData`, which is set on creation and only updated in `setMigrationDataFromDocumentContent`.

The whole result of `migrationParticipantsCandidates` could be cached and re-computed only in `setMigrationDataFromDocumentContent`.

title: NA
body:
After caching this sorted list of applicable candidates:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/e6714dc2-71d6-4728-a085-06f5f8d85dcf)

title: Improve the strategy used to merge extension registries
Optimize EObjectIdManager
body:
When loading a medium-sized model (~120k elements), a non trivial time is spent in various methods of EObjectIdManager:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/465c4aaf-2256-4250-8151-802831a2026a)

The current implementation uses stream operations, which are nice for readability but incur a significant overhead for performance-critical code.

title: NA
body:
Simply using lower-level ("old school") Java code significantly reduces the time used:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/e3e27fc2-77a5-4c6b-85d8-9e32e89d4097)

It seems there are more improvements possible but they would require changing the interface/protocol, notably getOrCreateId which, when an IdAdapter is not found, creates a new ID but does not add it to the object. This makes `JsonResource.attachedHelper()` do some duplicate work:

```java
String id = idManager.getOrCreateId(eObject);
this.setID(eObject, id);
```

with setId calling `findId` and then `setId`, and all 3 of `getOrCreateId`, `findId` and `setId` iterating at least once over all the adapters.

Another potential improvement which would require API change is that EMF JSON assumes ids can be any String, but in Sirius Web we use actual UUIDs. Calls to UUID.toString() to adapt to this mismatch is actually non trivial:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/ad794f3e-e3ed-4d18-8256-f76196d118b6)

Granted, it's only 2%, but still, 81ms spent just for this when loading a medium-sized model seems too much.

title: Add an extension point to contribute new representations
body:
In WorkbenchExtensionPoints.ts, add a new data extension point to contribute instances of :

```
type RepresentationComponentFactory = (representation: RepresentationMetadata): RepresentationComponent | null;
```

Then remove RepresentationContext, RepresentationContextValue, RepresentationComponentRegistry and use instead useData in Workbench.tsx to find all the representation component factories to find one that can display the representation. 

Delete also the RepresentationContextProvider and replace it with a contribution to the internal extension registry with one representation component factory extension per representation type.

The type Representation in Workbench.types.ts should be renamed to RepresentationMetadata to match its equivalent in the GraphQL API.

As a result, it will be possible to either add or replace the way representations should be displayed.

title: Avoid costly recomputations in RepresentationMigrationService
Add an extension point to contribute tabs to the project settings
body: Add an extension point in ProjectSettingsView.tsx to let contributor provide their settings tabs in the ProjectSettingsView.

title: RepresentationSearchService.migrateContent should not be called at all when not needed
body:
When opening a 2800 nodes diagram, we spend almost 400ms in RepresentationSearchService.migrateContent (and that is after having optimized `RepresentationMigrationService` to actually do nothing in this case, see #3555):

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/181ac7cb-2f35-470e-b1b4-ea53d20da245)

The time is spent:
* reading the ~3.8MB string into a `JsonTree`
* calling `migrationService.parseProperties`, which detects there is nothing to do in this case
* re-serializing the `JsontTree` into a String, identical to the original content.

title: Opening a diagram loads it up to 3 times; closing it reloads it too
body:
1. Put a breakpoint in `org.eclipse.sirius.web.application.representation.services.RepresentationSearchService.toRepresentation(String)` and start the app (new arch).
2. Open a project which contains at least one diagram.
3. Open the diagram: the breakpoint is hit 3 times.
4. Close the diagram: the breakpoint is hit once more.

I'll attach the stacks.

title: NA
body:
* [open-1.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/15566433/open-1.txt): the actual subscription which creates a `DiagramEventProcessorFactory` and loads the diagram inside of it.
* [open-2.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/15566434/open-2.txt): trying to find which representations can be created on the newly opened (and selected) representation (via `EditingContextRepresentationDescriptionsEventHandler`).
* [open-3.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/15566435/open-3.txt): trying to get the (non-existant) _Details_ view for the representation (via `PropertiesEventProcessorFactory`).
* [close.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/15566437/close.txt): the exact same stack as `open-2.txt`. The closed diagram is still considered selected, so its id is sent as the `objectId` in `getOnboardData`.


The second and third loads are probably relatively new behavior since #3066.

title: NA
body: This may be linked to the fact that now `ObjectService.getObject` supports representations so it loads them from the database

title: NA
body:
> This may be linked to the fact that now `ObjectService.getObject` supports representations so it loads them from the database

Yes, that's the #3066 I mentioned :)

body:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a new studio project
2. Create a Diagram Description and select it
3. In the Details view, focus on "Domain type".
4. Start typing "flow::S" and hit Ctrl-Space
5. Nothing happens. A proposal for "flow::System" should be visible (it is in the old arch)

This is beacause in the implementation of the completion proposal computation (`org.eclipse.sirius.components.view.emf.DomainTypeTextfieldCustomizer.getCompletionProposalsProvider()`) we look for all types visible in the current ResourceSet's PackageRegistry, but in the new architecture a Studio project's editing context only knows about the "studio level" (view) metamodels (see `org.eclipse.sirius.web.application.studio.services.StudioEditingContextInitializer`).

title: useConnector hook is called to many times
body:
`useConnector` hook is used in each connection target handles to get the value of `isConnectionInProgress, candidates, isReconnectionInProgress`
Because of this line `const connectionNodeId = reactFlowStore((state) => state.connectionNodeId);` `useConnector` is executed every-time the ReactFlow store changes.
Moreover, `useConnector` uses `useDiagramElementPalette` and this last hook is calling `useKeyPress`

We should reduce the dependencies between all these custom hooks.

title: Expanding/collapsing a node in the Explorer re-renders the whole workbench
body:
This is particularly visible when a large diagram is opened.

1. Open a project with two diagrams, one small (S) and one big (B).
2. Open S, select a element in the explorer.
3. Expand/collapse the element in the explorer, *not changing the selection*. The effect is immediate.
4. Open B instead of S, and repeat step 3, expanding/collapsing the same element. It is now very slow.

There is no actual selection change, but since `SelectionContextProvider`'s `setSelection` does not check that it calls `setState` with a new selection objet structurally equivalent but different in terms of identity. Now that the selection context is high in the component hierarchy, this re-renders the whole workbench, including the big diagram.

The solution is the same as in d995d6e79d41926f41290f0b4661a1ae118bc2b9: update the selection state if the key is new value is really structurally different from the previous one.

title: NA

```
<T extends IRepresentationEventProcessor> Optional<T> createRepresentationEventProcessor(Class<T>representationEventProcessorClass,
IRepresentationConfiguration configuration, IEditingContext editingContext);
```
to :
```
Optional<IRepresentationEventProcessor> createRepresentationEventProcessor(IRepresentationConfiguration configuration,
            IEditingContext editingContext);
```
In order to more easily create `RepresentationEventProcessor `when needed.

### Expected behavior
The `ExecuteEditingContextFunctionRunner` should return an `IPayload`, allowing to return an `ErrorPayload` if something went wrong during the handling of the input.
The `ExecuteEditingContextFunctionEventHandler` should catch exceptions thrown by the called function and return an `ErrorPayload` if such exception is caught.

title: When the Details view is visible, every change launches EMF's validation which is slow on large projects
body:
The scenario:

* Setup:
  * `sirius-web` application (DDD version), 2024.5.1
  * a project with the "Sirius Web" Papaya example and a diagram with 2831 nodes (no edges) opened
  * the explorer and details view are visible, 
  * an element is selected on the diagram, its details are shown
* Test:
  * change a boolean property of the selected object via its details view and measure the backend performance.

In this case it is expected that the backend:
1. performs the mutation (trivial)
2. saves the modified documents
3. refreshes the diagram, the explorer (tree) and the details view (form)

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/cca0393d-860d-4338-803c-8fbdcaae336d)

In the above flamegraph one can find these 3 refreshes:
1. in red on the left, the diagram's rendering (~250ms)
2. in blue in the middle, the explorer's tree rendering (~30ms)
3. in green on the right, the details view (form) rendering (~150ms), *largely dominated* by the invocation of `DiagnosticComponent.render` (~140ms), itself almost only spent inside EMF's `Dagnostician.validate`

title: Add an interface to customize outputevents of IRepresentationEventProcessor
Duplicate key exceptions in diagram layout handling can render a diagram unusable
body:
I don't have (yet) exact reproduction steps, but the general scenario is to have a relatively large project (e.g. the "Sirius Web" Papaya example) and a unsynchronized diagram opened (it can be almost empty). When creating several new nodes in rapid succession by DnD from the explorer, at some point on the frontend I get errors:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/0af21359-e280-41cc-9e71-390c3955e342)

On the backend I see several stack traces with messages like:

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Duplicate key 5193ff79-8b9a-3654-94a7-46add7d92364 (attempted merging values NodeLayoutData[id=5193ff79-8b9a-3654-94a7-46add7d92364, position=Position[x=-4763.55109521028, y=654.013054906542], size=Size[width=378.78125, height=770.0], resizedByUser=false] and NodeLayoutData[id=5193ff79-8b9a-3654-94a7-46add7d92364, position=Position[x=-4763.55109521028, y=654.013054906542], size=Size[width=378.78125, height=770.0], resizedByUser=false])
	at java.base/java.util.stream.Collectors.duplicateKeyException(Collectors.java:135) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.stream.Collectors.lambda$uniqKeysMapAccumulator$1(Collectors.java:182) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReduceOps$3ReducingSink.accept(ReduceOps.java:169) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.ArrayList$ArrayListSpliterator.forEachRemaining(ArrayList.java:1625) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:509) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.wrapAndCopyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:499) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReduceOps$ReduceOp.evaluateSequential(ReduceOps.java:921) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluate(AbstractPipeline.java:234) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline.collect(ReferencePipeline.java:682) ~[na:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.components.collaborative.diagrams.DiagramEventProcessor.handle(DiagramEventProcessor.java:138) ~[classes/:na]
```

I'm not sure exactly why we get duplicate keys here, but once they occur, the 2-args version of `Collectors.toMap()` we use throws an exception in the middle of the `DiagramEventProcessor.handle` execution, which is not handled and causes all kinds of issues.

I'll continue to invesitgate the root cause of the duplicates, but also propose an PR to use the 3-args version of `Collectors.toMap()` in the few places where we use the 2-args one to at least mitigate the consequences.

title: Simplifying the contribution to the GraphQL subscription of the diagram for custom nodes
Only save the documents actually impacted by a change
body:
Currently on every mutation (technically any handler which publishes a `SEMANTIC_CHANGE` change description, see `EditingContextEventProcessor.shouldPersistTheEditingContext(ChangeDescription)`) we save all the documents (EMF resources) in the project.
This can be long and is blocking (because EMF resources can not be safely used by multiple threads).

Ideally we would only save the "delta" of the change itself, and this might be possible but probably require a significant effort. A middle ground that seem to be worth investigating is to only save the sub-set of documents which are impacted by the change. Of course it would only be useful for _some_ projects (with data split in multiple resources) and _some_ changes (which do not recursively impact all/most of the resources).

EMF has native support for resource modification tracking (`resource.setTrackingModification(true)` on load, and then `resource.isModified()` to test the flag and `resource.setModified(false)` to reset it on save), so identifying which resources have been directly changed is trivial.

What's less trivial (but not that complicated) is that if resource _A_ has been changed and resource _B_ has not, the change in _A_ might still have an impact on _B_'s serialisation, if _B_ contains a reference to at least one object in _A_ whose URI has been modified by the change.

I'll try to prototype such an approach just to see if it's worth.

title: NA
body:
First (temporary) conclusion: the "optimization" does not gain much.

Computing the sub-set of resources that need to be saved is relatively slow (though I have some ideas to work around that), but most importantly, in the case of the "Sirius Web" Papaya example it does not gain much. For example, the "EObject" class in the "Eclipse EMF" resource, which should sit at the bottom of the dependencies and not be impacted by most changes contains an "Extended By" reference which makes it "dirty" as soon as any resource which defines a metamodel is touched.
So in practice because of this kind or references accross all layers, when flipping a simple boolean flag inside a class from "Sirius Components - Papaya" marks almost all the resources as potentially impacted and thus saved.

title: NA
body: Actually there were several issues with my first implementation. The "second round" version *does* show performance improvements, but I'm not quite sure it is correct. It might be fast(er) but actually broken.

title: NA
body:
With the "second round" version, I get down to about 270ms (from about 1000-1100ms before) when persisting the "Sirius Web" sample project after a single modification inside "Sirius Components - Tree":

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/ddcfbe4f-6a1e-43b6-890d-39b293523def)

In this case, all the time is now spent in `SemanticDataUpddateService.updateDocuments`:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/754a375f-01c6-4a55-9c1d-4525135db803)

*But* if the general approach (modulo some implementation bugs) is actually correct, the new `Set<UUID> unmodifiedDocumentIds` passed to that method, which is not used yet, could be exploited to also avoid writing the unmodified docs to the DB (not just avoid serializing them into JSON content):

title: NA
body:
A simpler version of this would be to avoid persisting anything when *nothing has actually changed*.

Currently when a tool is executed, it's handler has no way to know what semantic change it performed, or even *if* it actually performed a change. So all handlers publish a `ChangeKind.SEMANTIC_CHANGE` just to be safe. And then `EditingContextPersistenceService` *unconditionally* persists anything.

Even in normal functioning, there are cases where the user invokes a tool which does not actually perform any semantic change (for example the user request is invalid and rejected, or the tool's behavior does not actually *need* to make any change because the model is already in the expected state). In such a case we currently still persist the whole resource set.

If we enable EMF's resource modification tracking (and reset the `isModified` flag on actual save of course), `EditingContextPersistenceService` can safely bypass the whole persistence if it detects that no EMF resource is actually modified. This is very fast to test.

This would have a more limited impact than the approach outlined above, which is still relevant. But it seems like a safe "quick win" that can be done as a first step.

title: NA
body: A simple scenario (that is not the norm but not unrealistic either) is a user who: selects a node on a diagram, hits F2 to enter direct edit, changes his mind *and hits enter* (instead of Esc) to accept the current label. In this case we execute the direct edit tool (maybe the front should filter that, but it's another matter), do nothing (in most cases; of course that will depend on the tool's implementation), and save everything anyway.

title: NA
body: A simpler version (that can be built upon to get this finer grained one) is in https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/issues/3892.

title: getOrCreateEditingContextEventProcessor hits the database on every invocation
body:
`EditingContextEventProcessorRegistry#getOrCreateEditingContextEventProcessor` is invoked on every input to find (and create/load if necessary) the editing context event processor to dispatch the input to. It's on the critical path of almost every operation.

Currently the first thing it does is to test:
```java
if (this.editingContextSearchService.existsById(editingContextId)) {
```
before looking into the currently loaded event processors (`this.editingContextEventProcessors.get(editingContextId)`).

The `existsById` call ends up in `SemanticDataSearchService.existsByProject`, which will search into the database:

![Capture d’écran du 2024-06-18 09-58-18](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/1f097e35-8bda-4d86-9a0e-43177f339e04)

This means we hit the DB at least once for every input. In the nominal case, we will only receive requests for already loaded editing context. Once a project is loaded, it will probably receive thousands of inputs before becoming inactive and being disposed.

On my machine where PostgreSQL is running locally, just this test costs about 7ms. It's probably more when the DB is on a remote host (though I have not measured).

Technically, changing the order of the test (look for an already loaded editing context in the fast patch) could change the semantics if the project has just been removed from the database and its editing context event processor not yet disposed/removed, thought I'm not even sure this can happen.

title: NA
body:
Actually, I don't measure the expected gains. On a scenario where I simply change the selected node on a very small diagram (only two nodes, Explorer and Details view closed), I see the number of DB queries sent reduced (`existsByProjectId` is gone), and a small amount of time gained, but not much:

![Capture d’écran du 2024-06-18 14-41-05](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/16557f0f-791a-4699-80cf-bc59fb4d0cf4)

title: NA
body:
I'm not sure we can avoid this, at least not as simply as what the current PR does.

When *deleting* a project, `MutationDeleteProjectDataFetcher` invokes directly `IProjectApplicationService.deleteProject`, which ends up removing the data from the DB (via `ProjectDeletionService.deleteProject(UUID)`), but this is in the application layer.

Even though we publish a `ProjectDeletedEvent`, the code in e.g. `EditingContextEventProcessorRegistry` (or anything in Sirius Components) has no way to react to this, so it currently *must* ask the database for the current state (otherwise this leads to symptoms like #3829).

Note that the problem is more general than "just" `EditingContextEventProcessorRegistry#getOrCreateEditingContextEventProcessor`. **Every** GraphQL operation inside `Viewer#editingContext` passes through `ViewerEditingContextDataFetcher` which starts by testing if `this.editingContextApplicationService.existsById(editingContextId)`, and for the same reason the only way for it to get an up to date answer is to ask the DB.

This means that most interactions that seem inoccuous like clicking on an element in a diagram to get it's palette require (at least) one round trip to the database.

title: NA
body:
Note that have two different (but partially redundant?) paths used to test if an editing context with a given id exists. Both are invoked in a simple interaction like clicking on the background of a diagram and both call to the DB (with different queries):

One is in `EditingContextEventProcessorRegistry#getOrCreateEditingContextEventProcessor`, which tests for the existence of semantic data for this project id:

![Capture d’écran du 2024-07-31 16-10-50](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/00bdaf9a-931d-400f-b516-ee0917f59e77)

The second is in `ViewerEditingContextDataFetcher` which tests for the existence of the project corresponding to the editing context:

body:
> I'm not sure we can avoid this, at least not as simply as what the current PR does.
> 
> When _deleting_ a project, `MutationDeleteProjectDataFetcher` invokes directly `IProjectApplicationService.deleteProject`, which ends up removing the data from the DB (via `ProjectDeletionService.deleteProject(UUID)`), but this is in the application layer.

For this part of the problem, it might actually just be enough to add:
```java
this.editingContextEventProcessorRegistry.disposeEditingContextEventProcessor(input.projectId().toString());
```
in `MutationDeleteProjectDataFetcher` [as it existed before](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/87a8616792bbf8aa3500dae1143938c798dd80f6/packages/sirius-web/backend/sirius-web-graphql/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/graphql/datafetchers/mutation/MutationDeleteProjectDataFetcher.java).

title: NA
body:
See https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/pull/3901 for MutationDeleteProjectDataFetcher cleanup.

Otherwise, after discussion with @sbegaudeau we decided to keep the database lookup in place despite the potential performance hit as it ensures better consistency between the runtime data and the database, especially when mechanisms from e.g. #3897 are used.

title: Do not fetch representation content when we only need the metadata
body:
Scenario:
1. Open a diagram with several nodes.
2. Close all views (Explorer, Details) except the diagram.
3. Select a node.

Tested on: v2024.5.1-19-g62d42d0df.

The frontend sends two GraphQL queries to the backend (`getPalette` and `getToolSections`) which both take a significant amount of time (here on a medium/large diagram), resp. 51 and 54ms:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/9a096958-add8-4226-a7bc-261b7dd21b5e)

Looking at what's happening on the backend, most of this time is spent in `EditingContextRepresentationDataFetcher` calling `this.representationMetadataSearchService.findByRepresentationId(representationId)`:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/be636192-100a-4e49-916c-a4ecee835285)

`RepresentationMetadataSearchService.findByRepresentationId(representationId)` does:

```java
    @Override
    public Optional<RepresentationMetadata> findByRepresentationId(String representationId) {
        return this.representationMetadataProviders.stream()
                .filter(provider -> provider.canHandle(representationId))
                .map(provider -> provider.handle(representationId))
                .findFirst();
    }
```

First, the `IRepresentationMetadataProvider` API forces us to perform two separate calls (`canHandle` and `handle`), both of which will query the database in the case of persistent representations. This could probably be improved with a single `Optional<RepresentationMetadata> handle(String representationId)`.

Second, `PersistentRepresentationMetadataProvider.handle` will load the whole representation data, including the (potentially very large) `content`, which is not acutally used to build the `RepresentationMetadata` returned.

This could be avoided with a custom query `Optional<RepresentationData> IRepresentationDataRepository#findMetadataById(UUID id)` which returns an empty `content` and avoids loading that from the DB.

title: NA
body:
Same scenario after the change (PR coming):

![Capture d’écran du 2024-06-18 15-18-26](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/0fe0b76c-e275-4f7e-a4e3-a2b297e59ae4)

From 51+54=105ms before to 24+20=44ms (first try) or 15+12=27ms (second try) after. The second screenshot captured two different node selections.

On the backend:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/10608/28bee8f7-5cd7-4f3f-ba0d-8446997c924f)

Down from 42ms (or was it 2×42ms?) to only 2ms, and a query whose performance is independant on the size of the representation.

A temporary workaround is to select another element and _then_, re-click on the representation to open.

title: Avoid re-sending identical diagrams to the clients
body:
This is formulated about diagrams, but the issue is more general. It's just more impacting in terms of performance for diagrams which can quickly become large compared to the other kinds of representations (only large explorer trees with thousands of tree items could also be a problem I think for now).

The issue is that on any semantic change (in practice, any execution of a tool which *may* have a semantic impact, whether it actually *did* change something, see [this comment in another context](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/issues/3637#issuecomment-2194201390)) we must refresh/update all the active representations (e.g. diagrams) in the same editing context. Such is the open-ended nature of Sirius that we can not reliably predict, for a given tool execution or semantic change, which representations it will actually impact or not, so we must update all.

However, once the backend has done its work, i.e. `DiagramCreationService.refresh(IEditingContext, IDiagramContext)` has obtained the updated version of the `Diagram`, we unconditionally send the whole "new version" to all client browsers who currently display that diagram. For large diagrams this can have significant performance impact. It means we serialize the `Diagram` DTO as a GraphQL payload (with a non-trivial overhead in invoking all the field resolvers), potentially once per browser/client, and then send large amount of data (a medium-sized diagram can represent several megabytes of payload) to the clients, which *then* have to re-render it.

This whole process is required in the case where the new/updated version of the diagram is actually different from the previous one, but is 100% overhead when the diagram was not _actually_ impacted by the semantic change which triggered the refresh, and the newly computed diagram is identical to the previous one.

This not an uncommon case at all. It two users Alice and Bob are working on the same project, each in separate subsets of the project and with their own diagrams opened, any change by Alice in the semantic subset she is working on will trigger a refresh of both Alice & Bob's diagrams (which is normal), but also, in this case, re-sending the same diagram he currently has displayed to Bob for no reason.

title: NA
body:
A few remarks:
* Comparing `previousDiagram` and `diagram` in `DiagramCreationService.refresh` to detect if there was any actual change may not be free in terms of performance. This will need to be measured to see if the actual check will not be counter-productive.
* The current API of `DiagramCreationService.refresh()` would need to evolve to be able to return "nothing changed". It already returns an `Optional<Diagram`>, so there may be nothing to change in terms of Java types, but *the way this Optional is interpreted* by  `DiagramEventProcessor.refresh(ChangeDescription)` is that if the returned Optional is empty, it means the diagram could not be rendered, not that it was rendered and produced the same result as before.
* The "end game" for this whole subject would be to compute precise deltas of "what changed" between the two versions of a diagram and only send that. But that is much more complex and impacting and the first step of just computing a "did it change?" flag should already get us some benefit with limited risks.

body:
## Steps to reproduce

1. Open a project with at least one representation.
2. In the Explorer, select the semantic target element of a representation.
3. In the right panel, open the _Representations_ view. It should display the representation in question (with others if there are more).
4. Click on the "Delete" (trashcan) icon in the _Representations_ view to delete the representation.

The representation is not deleted, and we get error messages:

On the front:

> An unexpected error has occurred, please refresh the page

On the backend:

```
o.e.s.c.g.controllers.GraphQLController : {
  "errors" : [ {
    "message" : "The field at path '/deleteListItem' was declared as a non null type, but the code involved in retrieving data has wrongly returned a null value.  The graphql specification requires that the parent field be set to null, or if that is non nullable that it bubble up null to its parent and so on. The non-nullable type is 'DeleteListItemPayload' within parent type 'Mutation'",
    "path" : [ "deleteListItem" ],
    "extensions" : {
      "classification" : "NullValueInNonNullableField"
    }
  } ],
  "data" : null
}
```

title: It is necessary to load/open/render a representation (e.g. diagram) to delete it
body:
Currently the main way to delete a representation [^1] is through the context menu of the corresponding tree item in the explorer. Opening this context menu always _selects_ the item, which in turn will open the representation we want to delete. For large representations this can take a while and is counterproductive and frustrating as we want to _delete_ it.

Note that it's also true for renaming, which is something that technically we might want to do without opening the representation.

I guess an option (*if* we want to "fix" this) would be to allow for opening the context menu of items without selecting them (e.g. using a right click), but that may have other implications (the target tree item of the menu not being the currently selected item).

Another one, but that would change the workflow a lot, would be to decouple "select" (single click) from "open" (e.g. double click), in the same as e.g. in the Eclipse Explorer (where I don't have to *open* a (possible large) file just to delete/rename or otherwise operate on it.

[^1]: Technically there's another one, by selecting the target semantic element and using the "Representations" panel/view, which has a directly accessible "Delete" icon, but it's much less obvious/natural and probably much less known by users. ~~And [it seems broken in the new architecture at the moment](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/issues/3672)~~.

title: ReferenceWidgetConverterSwitch#getReferenceOptions should return the reference type candidates even if the owner is null or does not have the reference
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior

When an end-user clicks on a reference widget, the candidates (i.e. reference options) are computed and the displayed.
Currently, if the reference owner does not contains the reference, then the candidates are empty.

In some cases, it could be great to have the possibility to still returns the candidates corresponding to the type of the reference even if the owner does not contains the reference.
The reason is in some case, the owner will be created when the set of the reference is done (i.e. just before actually, but in the same operation).

title: NA

To retrieve a reference with only its name and without its containing eClass, it would imply to browse the whole metamodel and retrieve all references with the given name.

body:

![FormForIssue](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/121878084/bf8038df-c978-46c7-903b-67a98bf71f8b)

title: NA
body: This is caused by the fact that like diagrams, forms have a maximum depth fetched by the frontend (currently 4) so this issue would appear regardless of the widget used (a flexbox container and anything else). This is not a regression but a limitation that has always existed. We could push the maximum depth supported a bit further (5, 6, 7?) to cover most use cases

title: Multiple textfields in a form in a for is not working
body:
When editing the value of a textfield inside a for, the representation can become unresponsive
Here I'm not able to further edit the first edited value
![ForTextIssue](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/121878084/d7e7d00a-4f05-4c95-a9d3-ccc5360b4273)


https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/assets/121878084/4c29495e-f5d6-414d-949d-e92c8119f43d

title: NA
body:
This is on purpose, we cannot distinguish widgets that:

- are defined on the same semantic element
- with the same definition
- with the same label

And the end user cannot either. See ADR 108 for more details.

The only way we could really distinguish them would be by asking the specifier for an identifier for each widget instance (some sort of identifierExpression). It's the same in diagrams where you cannot have two nodes with the same:

- node description
- semantic element
- parent node
- containment kind (they are both a child or border node of their parent)

We can't distinguish them otherwise. Sirius desktop and web have never asked the specifier to provide such identification. It would be helpful for some tricky use cases but cumbersome for most use cases. It's also the same issue with multiple edges of the same kind between two nodes.

title: Add support for the duplication of semantic elements in the explorer
body:
An action to duplicate a semantic element should be available in the explorer. Thanks to this action, a dialog should be opened to let the end user select where the object will be duplicated. The target should be valid for such duplication, think for exemple about a mono-valued containment reference which may not be a valid target if it already has a child. The containment feature in the target object should be selectable too. Think for example about an object which has multiple containment references of the same type.

The duplication should be performed in a single action on the backend, nothing should be modified in the clipboard of the end user.

This dialog will should probably let the end user answer some open questions:

- Do we want to duplicate the child elements too?
- Do we want to duplicate outgoing references too ?
- Do we want to copy incoming references too (if they are multi-valued)

title: Helper lines should be activated by default
Frontend unit tests are tested on the CI but never compiled
body:
Since frontend unit tests are never compiled, they contain compilation errors that should be fixed.

In all frontend packages that have tests, next to the `tsconfig.json`, add a `tsconfig.test.json` containing:
```json
{
  "$schema": "https://json.schemastore.org/tsconfig",
  "extends": "./tsconfig.json",
  "include": ["./src/index.ts", "./src/**/__tests__/*.test.tsx"] <=== Can be adapted
}
```

Modify `package.json` `test` and `coverage` script to build tests with `tsconfig.test.json`: `tsc -p tsconfig.test.json && ...`.
Since there are no tests in  `sirius-web` package, remove the `test` script.

title: MigrationParticipant implementation broke conventional ExtendedMetadata mechanism
NA
body:
So after discussing with the persons involved with the migration service design and implementation, it was a voluntary decision not to base our version of `ExtendedMetaData` on EMF's `BasicExtendedMetaData` (nor delegate to it) as it is too tightly coupled with XML-based concepts which do not map well with our JSON resources.

That being said, the migration service's main use case for the time being (for semantic data) is for *us* (the Sirius Web project) to support transparent backward compatibility for instances of the _View_ and _Domain_ models. It would make sense to make the whole mechanism "opt in", explicitly ask for it on our side for these two kinds of semantic resources, and leave the EMF defaults as before for resources/documents where migration support is not explicitly asked for.

title: Reference widget does not work if placed in a flexboxContainer
body:
With the introduction of the custom widget extension point, we need to define an appolo documentTransform to add the fields to be retrieved to graphql queries.
However, with the current version for the reference widget, only the request to retrieve widgets at the root of the form (group) is overridden.
If the widget is in a flexboxContainer, then the graphql query is not modified.

### Expected behavior

Currently, RewriteProxiesEventHandler process all resources of the resource set, even read-only resources.
It could lead to issues if RewriteProxiesEventHandler try to modify such resources.
An improvement could be to filter resources in RewriteProxiesEventHandler, based on predicate provided by users.

It would also greatly improves project/resource upload time in case of project/resource upload involving lot of read-only resources like Sirius Web based application SysON where standard librairies are read-only.

title: Add optional support for loading/saving multiple EMF resources in parallel
body:
Currently `org.eclipse.sirius.web.application.editingcontext.services.EditingContextSearchService.loadSemanticData(EditingContext, SemanticData)` loads all the Documents inside a project sequentially inside the target EMF ResourceSet.

When a project's data is split across multiple documents, it is possible to load them in parallel, each in its own resource set, and only once they are all loaded to move them into the final, shared resource set.

Depending on how many documents there are and how many threads we assign to this, it can give a significant speedup (or not).

title: NA
body:
Locally, with 10 parallel threads I'm able to load a project with 1.2M elements (split across many resources) in about 2.5s, compared to about 15s when loading sequentially.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/814567a4-d2ef-4ba2-af27-ced65f968ecd

title: NA
body:
* `EditingContextPersistenceService.persist(IEditingContext)` could probably also be made to invoke `.map(this.resourceToDocumentService::toDocument)` in parallel. Could this be as simple as calling `.parallel()` on the stream of resources?
* *If* we decided to actually integrate this (it's currently more of an experiment), it should probably be configurable with:
  * a configurable `threshold` (in number of documents) above which parallel loading/saving is enabled. The default could be `-1` or `0` to disable the feature, and setting it to e.g. `5` would mean "only try to parallelize loading/saving of the project contains at least 5 resources/.documents"
  * a configurable number of threads to dedicate to this (the current code is hard-coded to `Executors.newFixedThreadPool(10)`).

title: Inactive editing contexts are sometimes not disposed
body:
I don't have a reproduction scenario yet, but opening this anyway and I will complete if I find more.

I'm working on performance when loading "large" projects (~100k semantic elements and more), where this is more obvious. In some cases, I have such a project opened, go back to the projects list, wait for the usual `disposeDelay` + [5 seconds](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/5f5ea28d365894c2681d585f7e29d7ba31357e9c/packages/core/backend/sirius-components-collaborative/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/components/collaborative/editingcontext/EditingContextEventProcessor.java#L366) with no representation opened on the project, and then reopen it.

I'm expecting the editing context to have been disposed and thus to reload (which is visible with large diagrams), but the project's content is visible immediately (in the explorer), which seem to indicate that something prevented the editing context to be disposed despite the inactive time.

title: NA
body: This might be related to earlier issues we had which might have been related to Apollo Client's `useSubscription`. The new version 3.11 (https://github.com/apollographql/apollo-client/releases/tag/v3.11.0) includes a rewrite of `useSubscription` which may fix that; we should try and upgrade and see if it fixes the issue.

title: Bump to ReactFlow12
If all representations are closed for long enough, no representation can be opened
body:
## Steps to reproduce:

1. Open a project which contains at least one representation; it should appear in the Onboarding area under _Open an existing Representation_. Do *not* open it yet.
2. Close/collapse both the _Explorer_ and _Details_ views/panels.
3. Wait for at least 6s (10s to be sure).
4. Click on the representation link in the onboard area: it should open but nothing happens.
5. Re-open the explorer: it opens correctly (though maybe with a small delay, as it is reloading the project), with the representation in question selected (as the explorer synchronizes with the workbench's selection).
6. Click on the representation in the _Explorer_: it does not open.
7. Select another element in the Explorer and then re-click on the representation: still nothing.
8. Create a *new* representation (e.g. diagram): it looks like it's created (it appears in the explorer) but does not open.

Note that the Explorer and Details view work fine even after that, so technically *some* representations (because they are transient?) can still be created.

It all seems to be caused by the editing context being disposed/unloaded at step 5 during the period when there is no active representation connected. The details are still not all clear (to me).

title: Only persist the editing context if there's been actual semantic changes
body:
Currently we persist the whole editing context any time a handler returns a `ChangeKind.SEMANTIC_CHANGE`.

Although it's not the common case, it's possible for a handler to return this `ChangeKind` even though the tool invoked did not actually perform any change in the semantic data (indeed, most tools' behavior is opaque to the handler which invoke them, so the handlers always assume the "worst" and suppose the tool *did* make some changes).

EMF has native support for resource modification tracking (`resource.setTrackingModification(true)` on load, and then `resource.isModified()` to test the flag, which is automatically reset on save), so identifying *if* any of the project's resources has actually been modified is trivial.

This is a simpler and safer subset of https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/issues/3637.

title: Memoizing the explorer
body:
Without memoizing the explorer, we can see that we have lots of rerender taking around 35ms, combining them all and we're loosing around 250ms every time we're selecting a node. This is with around 1k nodes so it would be more with more nodes.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c380ad22-65fc-4fb6-ba2d-17e7d19691c7)

Here memoizing the explorer we can get rid of these rerender and improve performances.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8b983766-3728-486c-96aa-11929111d571)

title: Several issues with the new support for arbitrary objects in the explorer
body:
Not sure if they are general issues of #3777 or specific to the way we excercised is with EMF Settings, but I noticed several issues. I'll add them all here, feel free to open separate issues for the ones the are actually relevant (and nor a misunderstanding on my part):

When expanding an Entity definition, I see a new 'superTypes' child, but it has no proper icon:

![Capture d’écran du 2024-08-29 16-19-47](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dd1b9097-8bcf-4e7d-9e2c-590322a4e6fd)

When I select the new node, I don't get anything in the Details view except "No object selected".

When the virtual node is visible multiple times, selecting one shows all the corresponding tree items as selected, it's confusing:

![Capture d’écran du 2024-08-29 16-27-53](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/59f91695-ba91-4714-88d7-974e4f57826b)

This is probably more specific to the way the new capability is used in the ExplorerDescriptionProvider, but now the same elements can appear multiple times in the explorer, and they have the same issue when one "instance" is selected:

![Capture d’écran du 2024-08-29 16-26-08](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0f81b2c1-9dae-492d-95c7-62f49bc524b4)

I have not checked (yet), but I suspect that if I create a reference loop with A extends B extends A (semantically invalid, but technically possible) and then try to "Expand All" on A, then I would trigger some kind of infinite loop.

The down caret is much closer to the hide tool (it overflows the active area) than the distribution tool section.

title: Some actions are (semi) enabled on read-only diagrams where they should not
body:
To put a diagram in read-only mode, the simplest way is to add it inside a portal and keep the portal in "Edit portal configuration" mode (the initial mode for newly created portals).

The following buttons in the diagram's toolbar are enabled but don't make much sense in read-only:
* Toggle snap to grid
* Show helper lines
* Smart Step Edge

Also, it is possible to *start* the interaction to reconnect an edge.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3becb233-11ad-43ac-a95e-e7e8740e6c21)

title: Flow editing context actions should not be available on blank project

```
     --spring.datasource.url=jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5433/sirius-web-db \

```

title: NA
body:
I'm using the Edge browser version 120.0.2210.89, and it seems to be an issue related to this: https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/issues/1848.
 It's a browser compatibility issue with the Crypto API: randomUUID(), as detailed here: https://caniuse.com/mdn-api_crypto_randomuuid. 
However, I see that Edge version 120 is supposed to support it. 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7e73e136-c05e-4a91-917a-cacff500c930)
I'll try upgrading Edge to version 127 and see if that helps.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Crypto/randomUUID

title: No visible error/feedback when trying to create a child element in an already "full" reference
body:

1. Create a studio
2. Create a View and Diagram Description.
3. The diagram comes with an already set "Diagram Palette" child and can contain only one.
4. In the diagram description's context menu, try to create a new one anyway (the choice is proposed in the dialog).

```
	at org.eclipse.sirius.web.application.object.controllers.MutationCreateChildDataFetcher.get(MutationCreateChildDataFetcher.java:33) ~[sirius-web-application-2024.7.11.jar!/:2024.7.11]
```

```
Caused by: org.springframework.context.NoSuchMessageException: No message found under code 'UPPER_BOUNDARY_REACHED' for locale 'en_US'.
```

Maybe it's "only" that `MessageSourceAccessor` is too strict, and if it did not fail we would get a proper error message propagated to the front?

title: Possible stack overflow when invoking "Expand All" on a domain
body:
Since the addition of support virtual nodes in the Explorer, and in particular support for [`EStructuralFeature.Setting`](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/blob/master/packages/sirius-web/backend/sirius-web-application/src/main/java/org/eclipse/sirius/web/application/views/explorer/services/ExplorerDescriptionProvider.java#L167), it is possible to create virtually infinite trees.

For example create a Domain definition with two entities A and B; set B as superType of A, and A as superType of B:


![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a051b675-b2f5-47b0-8c38-d12fd664f967)


Then try to invoke "Expand All" on either A or B:

```
java.util.concurrent.CompletionException: java.lang.StackOverflowError
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.encodeThrowable(CompletableFuture.java:315) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.uniComposeStage(CompletableFuture.java:1194) ~[na:na]
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.thenCompose(CompletableFuture.java:2309) ~[na:na]
	at graphql.GraphQL.parseValidateAndExecute(GraphQL.java:471) ~[graphql-java-22.0.jar:na]
	at graphql.GraphQL.lambda$executeAsync$9(GraphQL.java:429) ~[graphql-java-22.0.jar:na]

	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.thenCompose(CompletableFuture.java:2309) ~[na:na]
	at graphql.GraphQL.executeAsync(GraphQL.java:418) ~[graphql-java-22.0.jar:na]
	at graphql.GraphQL.execute(GraphQL.java:359) ~[graphql-java-22.0.jar:na]
	at org.eclipse.sirius.components.graphql.ws.handlers.StartMessageHandler.handle(StartMessageHandler.java:94) ~[classes/:na]
    [...]
Caused by: java.lang.StackOverflowError: null
	at java.base/java.util.HashMap.putVal(HashMap.java:627) ~[na:na]
```

body:
I reproduce this problem using UML workflow.

I would try to contribute a fix for this composed of two features:

First add an "ancestorIds" in the variable manager that keeps tracks of all parent ids of the current rendering TreeItem. This variable could be used to generate truly unique id for TreeItem. That would give the opportunity for the specifier to create such loop.

Add a security in Sirius Web that prevents the creating of a child if its id is contained in the "ancestorId" list. To make the user aware of the problem I would suggest to return a "Virtual" Tree item that show the possible infinite loop.

This item will have the same icon than the TreeItem causing the problem plus a warning sign. A prefix will be added to the label to identify the problem.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c6184ad1-1d6f-4922-bca7-09abd03ace28)

Do you think that could do the trick?

This contribution do not fix the "Expand All" action only the stackoverflow during the render phase.

It [**was** used](https://github.com/eclipse-sirius/sirius-web/pull/1020/files#diff-3c9a568dac19e8bf6f2c8a1bf8735729b90f435c250bf810207a80bdb59c2571R887) at some point, but it looks like something that has not yet been re-introduced in the new React Flow-based diagrams.

The other widgets become displayed in very light grey, which makes them hard to read.

title: NA
body: The thing is, the "click" and "double-click" behaviors on a list item are specifier-defined, so they *can* actually execute changes (see `mutation clickListItem()` which invoke `ListItem`'s `Function<ClickEventKind, IStatus> clickHandler` which can perform whatever).

title: NA
body: Actually, it makes sense to only avoid the mutation invocations themselves when readOnly, but not the `setSelection` which is also performed in this case, and could make sense even in read-only.

title: Using # in parameters of the structure id cause a lot of issue when parsing the id as URL
body:
A new way to passing information between the front end and the back end is to encode everything in a unique structure id.

Those is look lile: protocole://path?param1=XXX&param2=YYY

The values "XXX" and "YYY" should be encoded to avoid passing the "#" char.

This char as a special meaning when parsing the id as a URL. It is used to identified the fragment part of the URL.

If those value contains "#" then all arguments after "#" are ignored since consider as fragment.

For example, the _DefaultIdentityService_ has a fallback that use the fragment of the EObject as ID if no IDManager is found. Those ids often look like this "AAA#N". When those element are displayed into a tree and then expanded the expandedIds list contains "[AAA#N]" causing a problem in the URLParser code.

In all backend and frontend, the parameters value should be encoded and decoded to avoid such a problem.

title: When an element selected in the workbench appears on a diagram, it should be selected on the diagram
body:
### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Flow project with a "Topography unsynchronized" diagram.
2. Open it on two different browser windows (not strictly necessary, but it's a case that should work too).
3. In both windows, select the _CompositeProcessor1_ element. The diagram does not currently show this element (it's empty), so there's nothing to select there.
4. In one of the windows, drop _CompositeProcessor1_ on the diagram. A corresponding node appears on both windows, the _CompositeProcessor1_ is still selected in the Explorer and Details view, but the corresponding diagram element is *not* selected.

This breaks the invariant (never explicited but which seems natural) that "the elements which appear selected on a diagram correspond exactly to the graohical representations of the semantic elements selected in the workbench".

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0d3cb34b-65f9-4071-8f39-33f9c971f954

title: Browser Back/Forward actions do not work
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this bug has not yet been reported by someone else**
* [x] **I have checked that this bug appears on Chrome**
* [x] **I have specified the version** :
- latest
* [x] **I have specified my environment** : 
- All

### Steps to reproduce

- open a diagram A
- check that the URL ends with A id
- open another diagram B
- check that the URL ends with B id
- click on the "Back" button of the browser

### Expected behavior

- the URL changes with A id
- A is opened

### Actual behavior

- Nothing happens besides the Back button being now disabled

title: NA
body:
Actually, "Nothing happens" is not technically true, its a little more subtle.

We correctly switch back to the previous URL temporarily, but the code in `EditProjectView.tsx`, seeing that the `representationId`  in the URL (A, the old one we try to go back to) and the one considered current in the state machine (B, the one we come from before hitting "Back") do not match, interprets this as "we were displaying A, but the user has selected B, so navigate to B's URL".

title: Error when deleting Resource that use EReference.isContainer feature
body:
When trying to delete a Resource that contains element that with EReference that are isContainer the process fails with the following error (see above).

The problem is due to the removal of that EReference that is in fact an EOpposite reference of a containment feature. This removal modify the containment tree while iterating on it.

```java
private Collection<Setting> getNonContainmentReferences(Collection<Setting> inverseReferences) {
        Collection<Setting> nonContainmentReferences = new ArrayList<>();
        for (EStructuralFeature.Setting setting : inverseReferences) {
            EStructuralFeature eStructuralFeature = setting.getEStructuralFeature();
            if (eStructuralFeature instanceof EReference) {
                EReference eReference = (EReference) eStructuralFeature;
                if (!eReference.isContainment() && !eReference.isDerived()) {
                    nonContainmentReferences.add(setting);
                }
            }
        }
        return nonContainmentReferences;
    }


private void clearReferencesTo(EObject referencedObject) {
        Collection<Setting> settings = this.getInverseReferences(referencedObject);

        if (settings != null) {
            for (Setting setting : this.getNonContainmentReferences(settings)) {
                try {
                    if (referencedObject.eResource() == null || referencedObject.eResource().getResourceSet() == null) {
                        EcoreUtil.remove(setting, referencedObject);
                    }
                } catch (NullPointerException e) {
                    // thrown when trying to remove from an object that is present in the being removed Resource.
                    // But we do not care about this resource.
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    
    private void handleRemoveEObject(EObject eObject) {
        // Remove all inverse references
        this.clearReferencesTo(eObject);
        TreeIterator<Object> allProperContents = EcoreUtil.getAllProperContents(eObject, false);
        while (allProperContents.hasNext()) { //<-- Iteration on a modified tree
            Object object = allProperContents.next();
            if (object instanceof EObject) {
                this.clearReferencesTo((EObject) object);
            }
        }

        // clean the crossRefererenceAdapter
        this.unsetTarget(eObject);
    }
````

Those feature should not be removed since they will be removed with the resource removal.

title: Collapsible element re-expands when child element is selected
body:
When a collapsible element is collapsed and a child element is selected, the parent element automatically re-expands. This occurs because we automatically expands elements in the tree structure to ensure the selected element is visible. However, this behavior can be undesirable when the parent element is not selectable, as it causes the parent to re-expand unnecessarily.

### Expected behavior

The parent element should remain collapsed, even if a child element is selected.

### Actual behavior

![model-browser-reveal-selected](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f99924bc-ceb9-44d2-a673-1f9beb38a8e4)

Possible solution:

One possible solution to this issue is to clear the selection when a non-selectable element is clicked, such as when collapsing a parent element. This would prevent the parent element from re-expanding unnecessarily."

title: Make outside and edge labels draggable
Project template cards do not display a loading indicator when used inside the project template dialog
Add support for copy / paste tools
body:
* [x] **I have checked that this feature has not yet been suggested by someone else.**

### Expected behavior
When a node is selected on a diagram, and the user hits `ctrl + v` (or `meta + v`), the direct edit of the element should trigger (if any), and the initial content of the direct edit field should contain the content of the clipboard.

### Cuttings backs
This issue focuses on diagrams, and doesn't address direct edit in other representations.

### Potential side effects
This feature may create a conflict with a future implementation of copy/paste in Sirius Web.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

title: NA
body: Given the fact that there was a copy / paste tool in Sirius Desktop I don't think we will trigger the direct edit on this action. It would instead trigger a paste tool (which do not exist)

title: NA
body:
This makes sense, once paste tools will be implemented I'll probably find a way to do what I want with direct edit if needed.
I'll close the associated PR.

```
java.util.concurrent.CompletionException: The field at path '/formEvent' was declared as a non null type, but the code involved in retrieving data has wrongly returned a null value. The graphql specification requires that the parent field be set to null, or if that is non nullable that it bubble up null to its parent and so on. The non-nullable type is 'RepresentationMetadata' within parent type 'PieChart'
```

### Actual behavior
